revision.text:
{{Year box}} [[Image:JoeGans.jpg|thumb|200px|right|World lightweight [[boxing]] champion [[Joe Gans]]]] '''1902 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[Rose Bowl Game|Rose Bowl]] (1901 season): ** The [[Michigan Wolverines]] won 49-0 over the [[Stanford Indians]] to win the college football national championship * [[Michigan Wolverines]] – [[college football]] national championship
'''Professional championships''' * [[National Football League (1902)|National Football League champions]] – [[Pittsburgh Stars]] * [[Ohio League|Ohio League champions]] – [[Akron East Ends]]
'''Events''' * 1 January — inaugural [[Rose Bowl (game)|Rose Bowl]] game is played at [[Pasadena, California]] * September — the first professional football league, the [[National Football League (1902)]], which is unrelated to the current [[NFL]], is formed from three teams based in [[Pennsylvania]] and who are backed by [[Major League Baseball]]. The league folds a few months later. * 21 November — the [[Philadelphia Athletics (NFL)|Philadelphia Football Athletics]] defeated the [[Kanaweola Athletic Club]] of [[Elmira, New York|Elmira]], [[New York (state)|New York]], 39–0, in the first ever professional [[American football]] [[night game]]. * 29 November — the [[Pittsburgh Stars]] defeated the Philadelphia Football Athletics, 11–0, at the [[Recreation Park (Pittsburgh)|Pittsburgh Coliseum]], to win the 1902 National Football League championship. * 28 December — the [[Syracuse Athletic Club]] [[World Series of Football (1902–1903)|defeated]] the [[New York (World Series of Football)|New York Philadelphians]], 5–0, in the [[indoor American football|first indoor professional American football]] game, which was held at [[Madison Square Garden (1890)|Madison Square Garden]].
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * [[The Football League]] – [[Sunderland FC|Sunderland]] 44 points, [[Everton FC|Everton]] 41, [[Newcastle United]] 37, [[Blackburn Rovers]] 36, [[Nottingham Forest]] 35, [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] 35 * [[1902 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] 2–1 [[Southampton FC|Southampton]] at [[Crystal Palace National Sports Centre|Crystal Palace]], London (replay following 1–1 draw at Crystal Palace) * 26 April — shortly after being saved from bankruptcy, [[Manchester United F.C.|Newton Heath]] changes its name to Manchester United '''Scotland''' * [[Scottish Football League]] – [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] * [[1902 Scottish Cup Final|Scottish Cup final]] – [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] 1–0 [[Glasgow Celtic|Celtic]] at [[Celtic Park]] '''Spain''' * 10 March — foundation of [[Real Madrid]] as Madrid Fútbol Club
==[[Athletics (sport)|Athletics]]== * [[Sammy Mellor]] wins the sixth running of the [[Boston Marathon]].<ref name="BAA 1901-1905">{{cite web |url=http://www.baa.org/races/boston-marathon/boston-marathon-history/race-summaries/1901-1905.aspx |title=Boston Marathon History: 1901-1905 |first= |last= |author=Boston Athletic Association |authorlink=Boston Athletic Association |coauthors= |date= |month= |year=2011 |work=www.baa.org |publisher=Boston Athletic Association |location=Boston |page= |pages= |at= |language= |trans-title=|format= |doi= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |accessdate=March 2, 2011 |quote= |ref= |separator= |postscript=}}</ref>
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''VFL Premiership''' * [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]] wins the 6th [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership: Collingwood 9.6 (60) d [[Essendon Football Club|Essendon]] 3.9 (27) at [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] (MCG) * With a handful of exceptions, all VFL/AFL Grand Finals are played at the MCG from 1902
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * [[National League]] championship – [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] * [[American League]] championship – [[Oakland Athletics|Philadelphia Athletics]] '''Events''' * 23 April — [[infielder]] [[Lou Castro]] debuts with the [[Oakland Athletics|Philadelphia Athletics]] in the [[American League]] as the first Latin-American to play in [[Major League Baseball]] * [[Winnipeg Maroons]] wins the inaugural [[Northern League (baseball, 1902-71)|Northern League]] Championship in the [[Minor League Baseball|minor leagues]]
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * [[Joe Gans]] wins the [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship by knocking out [[Frank Erne]] in the first round. Gans successfully defends the title five times by the end of the year. * 25 July — [[James J. Jeffries]] defeats [[Bob Fitzsimmons]] by an eighth-round knockout in San Francisco, Fitzsimmons failing in his bid to recover the [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[James J. Jeffries]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Tommy Ryan]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Barbados Joe Walcott]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Frank Erne]] → [[Joe Gans]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Young Corbett II]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Harry Forbes]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * No cricket is played in South Africa due to the [[Boer War]]. * [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] defeats [[England national cricket team|England]] in [[The Ashes]] by 2 [[Test cricket|Tests]] to 1 after the first two Tests have been rained off. In one of the most famous Test series in history, the final three matches are full of drama with [[Victor Trumper]] scoring a [[century (cricket)|century]] before lunch in the Third Test, Australia winning the Fourth Test by just 3 runs and England winning the Fifth Test by one wicket following a [[century (cricket)|century]] in only 75 minutes by [[Gilbert Jessop]]. '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Yorkshire CCC|Yorkshire]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – [[Wiltshire CCC|Wiltshire]] * Most runs – [[Victor Trumper]] 2570 @ 48.49 (HS 128) * Most wickets – [[Wilfred Rhodes]] 213 @ 13.15 (BB 8–26) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]] – [[Warwick Armstrong]], [[Cuthbert Burnup]], [[James Iremonger]], [[James Kelly (cricketer)|James Kelly]], [[Victor Trumper]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[New South Wales cricket team|New South Wales]] * Most runs – [[Clem Hill]] 1035 @ 51.75 (HS 107) * Most wickets – [[Len Braund]] 62 @ 28.69 (BB 6–90) '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular|Bombay Presidency]] – [[Europeans cricket team|Europeans]] shared with [[Parsees cricket team|Parsees]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – not contested '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – not contested
==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * [[1902 World Figure Skating Championships|World Men's Champion]] – [[Ulrich Salchow]] (Sweden)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1902 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Sandy Herd]] * [[1902 U.S. Open (golf)|US Open]] – [[Laurie Auchterlonie]], who becomes the first golfer to break 80 in all four rounds of the US Open '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[Charles Hutchings (golfer)|Charles Hutchings]] * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] – [[Louis N. James]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1902 Grand National|Grand National]] – Shannon Lass * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Sceptre (horse)|Sceptre]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Sceptre * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Ard Patrick]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Sceptre * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – Sceptre '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – The Victory '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Lyddite '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Patlander * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – St. Brendan '''USA''' * [[1902 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Alan-a-Dale * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Old England * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Masterman
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Stanley Cup''' * [[Winnipeg Victorias]] successfully defends the [[Stanley Cup]], defeating [[Toronto Wellingtons]] in a Cup challenge by two games to nil in a best-of-three series * March – Winnipeg Victorias wins the Manitoba Hockey Association championship to retain the Stanley Cup * 1 March — [[Montreal Hockey Club|Montreal HC]] wins the [[Canadian Amateur Hockey League]] (CAHL) championship and challenges Winnipeg * 13–17 March — Montreal and Winnipeg play a best-of-three series for the Stanley Cup, Montreal winning by two games to one to claim the Stanley Cup for the first time since 1894
==[[Motor racing]]== '''Paris-Vienna Trail''' * The Paris-Vienna Trail is run on 26–29 June over 990 km and won by [[Marcel Renault]] (France) driving a [[Renault]] in a time of 15:47:43. The race is in retrospect sometimes referred to as the ''VII Grand Prix de l'ACF''.<ref>[http://www.teamdan.com/archive/gen/upto1903/1902.html 1902 Grand Prix and Paris Races]. Retrieved on 12 September 2009.</ref> '''Gordon Bennett Cup''' * The third [[Gordon Bennett Cup in auto racing|Gordon Bennett Cup]] is run from Paris to Innsbruck and won by [[Selwyn Edge]] (Great Britain) driving a [[D. Napier & Son|Napier 30hp]]. '''Circuit des Ardennes''' * The inaugural Circuit des [[Ardennes]] is run on 31 July 1902 in the vicinity of [[Bastogne]]. The total distance is 512.05 km (i.e., 85.34 km x 6 laps). The winner is [[Charles Jarrott (racing driver)|Charles Jarrott]] (Great Britain), driving a [[Panhard-Levassor]] 70 hp in a time of 5:53:39. '''Great Britain''' * The first motor race in Great Britain is held at [[Bexhill-on-Sea]] with more than 200 entries.<ref>[http://www.discoverbexhill.com/bexhillmotorracing.php Birthplace of British motor racing]. Retrieved on 16 August 2009.</ref>
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 22 March — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 59th [[The Boat Race 1902|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby league]]== '''Events''' * [[Featherstone Rovers]] founded '''England''' * [[Rugby Football League Championship|Championship]] – [[Broughton Rangers]] * [[Challenge Cup|Challenge Cup final]] – [[Broughton Rangers]] 25–0 [[Salford Red Devils|Salford]] at [[Athletic Grounds, Rochdale]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Lancashire League Championship]] – [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Yorkshire League Championship]] – [[Leeds Rhinos|Leeds]]
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Home Nations Championship''' * 20th [[Six Nations Championship|Home Nations Championship]] series is won by [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]]
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * [[1902 World Allround Speed Skating Championships|Men's All-round Champion]] – ''none declared''
==[[Tennis]]== '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Laurence Doherty]] (GB) defeats [[Arthur Gore (tennis)|Arthur Gore]] (GB) 6–4 6–3 3–6 6–0 * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Muriel Robb]] defeats [[Charlotte Cooper Sterry]] 7–5 6–1 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Michel Vacherot]] defeats [[Max Decugis]] 6–4 6–2 * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Françoise Masson]] defeats P Girod: details unknown '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[William Larned]] defeats [[Reginald Doherty]] (GB) 4–6 6–2 6–4 8–6 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Marion Jones (tennis)|Marion Jones]] defeats [[Elisabeth Moore]] 6–1 1–0 retired '''Davis Cup''' * [[1902 International Lawn Tennis Challenge]] – {{davis|USA|1896}} 3–2 {{davis|GBR|name=British Isles}} at Crescent Athletic Club (grass) [[Brooklyn]], [[United States]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1901 – 1950}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1902 in sports| ]]

{{TennisEventInfo|2010|Abierto Internacional del Bicentenario Leon| | date=April 12 – April 18 | edition=8 | location=[[León, Guanajuato]], [[Mexico]] | champs={{flagicon|MEX}} [[Santiago González (tennis)|Santiago González]] | champd={{flagicon|MEX}} [[Santiago González (tennis)|Santiago González]] / {{flagicon|CAN}} [[Vasek Pospisil]] }}
The '''2010 [[Abierto Internacional del Bicentenario Leon]]''' was a professional [[tennis]] tournament played on [[Tennis court#Hard courts|Hard courts]]. It was part of the [[2010 ATP Challenger Tour]]. It took place in [[León, Guanajuato]], [[Mexico]] between 12 and 18 April 2010.
==ATP entrants== ===Seeds=== {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Nationality ! Player ! Ranking* ! Seeding |- | {{flag|POL}} | [[Michał Przysiężny]] | 105 | 1 |- | {{flag|AUS}} | [[Greg Jones (tennis)|Greg Jones]] | 196 | 2 |- | {{flag|GER}} | [[Andre Begemann]] | 198 | 3 |- | {{flag|IND}} | [[Prakash Amritraj]] | 200 | 4 |- | {{flag|USA}} | [[Lester Cook]] | 215 | 5 |- | {{flag|MEX}} | [[Santiago González (tennis)|Santiago González]] | 217 | 6 |- | {{flag|IRL}} | [[Conor Niland]] | 228 | 7 |- | {{flag|KOR}} | [[Im Kyu-tae]] | 238 | 8 |} * Rankings are as of April 5, 2010.
===Other entrants=== The following players received wildcards into the singles main draw: * {{flagicon|MEX}} [[Juan-Manuel Elizondo]] * {{flagicon|MEX}} [[Daniel Garza]] * {{flagicon|MEX}} [[Alfredo Moreno (tennis)|Alfredo Moreno]] * {{flagicon|MEX}} [[César Ramírez (tennis)|César Ramírez]]
The following players received entry from the qualifying draw: * {{flagicon|AUS}} [[Kaden Hensel]] * {{flagicon|USA}} [[Travis Rettenmaier]] * {{flagicon|SUI}} [[Roman Valent]]
==Champions== ===Singles=== {{main|2010 Abierto Internacional del Bicentenario Leon – Singles}} {{flagicon|MEX}} '''[[Santiago González (tennis)|Santiago González]]''' def. {{flagicon|POL}} [[Michał Przysiężny]], 3–6, 6–1, 7–5
===Doubles=== {{main|2010 Abierto Internacional del Bicentenario Leon – Doubles}} {{flagicon|MEX}} '''[[Santiago González (tennis)|Santiago González]]''' / {{flagicon|CAN}} '''[[Vasek Pospisil]]''' def. {{flagicon|AUS}} [[Kaden Hensel]] / {{flagicon|AUS}} [[Adam Hubble]], 3–6, 6–3, [10–8]
==References== *[http://www.protennislive.com/posting/2010/1539/x.pdf 2010 Draws] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100421043044/http://www.torneoscasablanca.com.mx/index.html Official website] *[http://www.itftennis.com/mens/tournaments/tournamentSearch.asp ITF search]
{{2010 ATP Challenger Tour}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Anaheim Ice| nickname =| logo_image = | image = Anaheimice.jpg| location = 300 West Lincoln Avenue
[[Anaheim, California]]| coordinates = {{coord|33.833907|-117.917424|display=inline,title}}| broke_ground = | opened = 1995| closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Anaheim Ducks]]| operator = Anaheim Ducks| surface = 200' x 85'| construction_cost= | architect = [[Frank Gehry]]| former_names = Disney Ice| tenants =[[USC Trojans]] ([[Pacific 8 Intercollegiate Hockey Conference|PAC-8]]) (1995–present)
[[Anaheim Ducks]] (practice facility)| seating_capacity = | publictransit = | website = [http://anaheimice.therinks.com/ Official website] }} '''Anaheim Ice''', formerly known as '''Disney Ice''', is an [[Ice rink|indoor ice rink complex]] in [[Anaheim, California]]. It is known for being one of the major works of [[architect]] [[Frank Gehry]]. It is the practice and training rink of the [[Anaheim Ducks]] of the [[National Hockey League]], and also hosts youth hockey, [[figure skating]] events, and public skating. Additionally, it serves as the home rink for the [[University of Southern California]] club hockey team,[http://www.uscicehockey.com USC Ice Hockey website] and was the site of the 2010 PAC-8 Hockey Conference Tournament, hosted by USC.[http://www.facebook.com/pages/PAC-8-Hockey-Conference-Tournament/271408391159 PAC-8 Conference Tournament Facebook page] ==History== Disney Ice was commissioned by [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney's]] then-CEO [[Michael Eisner]], who said, "I was looking for the next generation of American architects -- and he was on the list of architects who were pushing the envelope. We bought a hockey team. We needed a practice rink."[https://www.pbs.org/wnet/americanmasters/database/gehry_pop/disneyice.html American Masters: Frank Gehry], PBS The facility resembles a pair of huge [[quonset hut]]s, and has a wooden interior with laminated beams and braces, producing "a nautical effect that recalls the inverted ship shape of Gehry's Disney Concert Hall". {{cite news | last = Muschamp | first = Herbert | coauthors = | title = Architecture View: Disney Takes the Ice to the Players | work = | pages = | language = | publisher = The New York Times | date = 1994-09-18 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/18/arts/architecture-view-disney-takes-the-ice-to-the-players.html | accessdate = 2007-01-17}} It opened in 1995. When the Anaheim Ducks (then known as the Mighty Ducks of Anaheim) were sold to [[Henry Samueli]] and his wife Susan in 2005, Disney Ice was also sold to the Samuelis, who renamed it Anaheim Ice. == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://anaheimice.therinks.com/ Official website] {{Anaheim Ducks}} {{University of Southern California}} {{Frank Gehry}} [[Category:Anaheim Ducks]] [[Category:USC Trojans sports venues]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1995]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in California]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1995]] [[Category:Sports venues in Anaheim, California]] [[Category:Disney sports]] [[Category:1995 establishments in California]] [[Category:Frank Gehry buildings]] [[Category:National Hockey League practice facilities]] [[Category:College ice hockey venues in the United States]] {{California-stadium-stub}} {{icehockey-venue-stub}}

The '''''Apito Dourado''''' (Golden Whistle) affair is a sports [[match fixing|corruption]] scandal in [[Football in Portugal|Portuguese football]] that first arose in 2004. Portuguese Judiciary Police (''[[Polícia Judiciária]]'') investigators named several football personalities as suspects (''[[arguido]]s'') of corrupting or attempting to corrupt referees, including [[Jorge Nuno Pinto da Costa]], chairman of [[FC Porto]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Vernet-Riera|first=Josep|date=21 January 2010|title=FC Porto: Leaked Phone Taps Proof in Major Corruption Scandal|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/330214-fc-porto-leaked-phone-taps-proof-major-corruption-scandal|website=Bleacher Report|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|date=3 December 2004|title=Police raid HQ of European champions Porto|url=http://www.abc.net.au/sport/content/200412/s1257302.htm|dead-url=yes|agency=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]]|website=ABC Sport|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041204055737/http://www.abc.net.au/sport/content/200412/s1257302.htm|archive-date=4 December 2014|access-date=15 September 2017}}</ref> and the former [[Boavista F.C.]] chairman and [[Portuguese League for Professional Football]] President [[Valentim Loureiro]].<ref>{{cite news|date=20 April 2004|title=Portugal football bosses arrested|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3643515.stm|website=BBC News|access-date=15 September 2017}}</ref> Although less notorious, a major part of the affair involved lower division referees and clubs, namely [[UD Sousense]] and [[Gondomar S.C.]], and club officials.
In December 2006, Pinto da Costa's former partner [[Carolina Salgado]] published the book ''[[Eu, Carolina]]'' ("Me, Carolina"), in which she made serious accusations against him. Pinto da Costa called these accusations "absurd" and said he would address them in court.<ref>{{cite news|date=12 December 2006|title=Pinto da Costa não comenta acusações|trans-title=Pinto da Costa does not comment accusations|url=http://www.tsf.pt/online/desporto/interior.asp?id_artigo=TSF176083|dead-url=yes|language=Portuguese|website=TSF|archive-url=http://archive.fo/hERM|archive-date=13 September 2012|access-date=15 September 2017}}</ref> Salgado's book caused the two cases in which Pinto da Costa was involved that had already been dismissed to be re-opened.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gomes|first1=Joaquim|last2=Rita|first2=Pedro|date=9 December 2006|title=Carolina Salgado testemunha da Judiciária|trans-title=Carolina Salgado - Judiciária's witness|url=http://www.correiodamanha.pt/noticia.asp?id=223726&idselect=133&idCanal=133&p=22|dead-url=yes|language=Portuguese|website=Correio da Manhã|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928014229/http://www.correiodamanha.pt/noticia.asp?id=223726&idselect=133&idCanal=133&p=22|archive-date=28 September 2007|access-date=15 September 2017}}</ref>
In March 2008, [[Porto]]'s Tribunal de Instrução Criminal decided that one of these cases, concerning a match between FC Porto and [[S.C. Beira-Mar|Beira-Mar]] where Pinto da Costa allegedly delivered an envelope containing €2,500 to a referee, would proceed to trial.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pontes|first1=Carlos|last2=Ferris|first2=Ken|date=25 March 2008|title=Soccer-Porto president to stand trial for alleged bribery|url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/soccer-europe-porto/soccer-porto-president-to-stand-trial-for-alleged-bribery-idUKL2587848820080325|website=[[Reuters]]|access-date=15 September 2017}}</ref> The other major case involving FC Porto and Pinto da Costa, regarding a match between FC Porto and [[C.F. Estrela da Amadora|Estrela da Amadora]], where FC Porto allegedly offered prostitutes to the match referees, was dismissed for the second time in June 2008 and the main accusation witness, Salgado, accused of perjury.<ref>{{cite news|last=Cabrita|first=Felícia|date=30 June 2008|title=Pinto da Costa não vai a julgamento e Carolina Salgado acusada de falsas declarações|trans-title=Pinto da Costa will not go to trial and Carolina Salgado accused of false statements|url=https://sol.sapo.pt/PaginaInicial/Sociedade/Interior.aspx?content_id=99944|dead-url=yes|language=Portuguese|newspaper=[[Sol (newspaper)|Sol]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080922092822/http://sol.sapo.pt/PaginaInicial/Sociedade/Interior.aspx?content_id=99944|archive-date=22 September 2008|access-date=15 September 2017}}</ref>
In July 2008, Valentim Loureiro was found guilty of abuse of power but not guilty of corruption. He was sentenced to three years and two months of suspended jail time.<ref>{{cite news|date=18 July 2008|title=Valentim condenado a três anos e dois meses de prisão com pena suspensa por abuso de poder|trans-title=Valentim sentenced to two years and two months of suspended jail time for abuse of power|url=https://tsf.sapo.pt/paginainicial/Portugal/interior.aspx?content_id=969333|dead-url=yes|language=Portuguese|website=[[TSF (radio)|TSF]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081203074740/http://tsf.sapo.pt/paginainicial/Portugal/interior.aspx?content_id=969333|archive-date=3 December 2008|access-date=15 September 2017}}</ref>
In May 2008, the disciplinary committee of the [[Liga Portuguesa de Futebol Profissional|Portuguese Professional Football League]], who had opened a parallel non-criminal proceeding called '''''Apito Final''''' (Final Whistle), sentenced Pinto da Costa to a two-year suspension and FC Porto was docked six points in the [[Primeira Liga]] and fined €150,000 for attempted bribery;<ref name="uefa ban">{{cite news|date=4 June 2008|title=Porto not admitted to Champions League|url=http://www.uefa.com/news/newsid=705421.html|website=UEFA|access-date=15 September 2017}}</ref> Boavista FC was sentenced to relegation for bribery and referee coercion, and fined €180,000; [[U.D. Leiria|União de Leiria]] lost three points and its chairman, [[João Bartolomeu]], was sentenced to a one-year suspension.<ref>{{cite news|date=9 May 2008|title=FC Porto perde seis pontos|trans-title=FC Porto lose six points|url=http://pt.uefa.com/memberassociations/association=por/news/newsid=693895.html|language=Portuguese|website=UEFA|access-date=15 September 2017}}</ref> FC Porto recovered those points in July 2017.<ref>{{cite news|date=15 July 2017|title=Justiça desportiva iliba Pinto da Costa no caso Apito Final|trans-title=Sports justice exonerates Pinto da Costa in the Apito Final affair|url=https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/empresas/desporto/detalhe/justica-desportiva-iliba-pinto-da-costa-no-caso-apito-final|language=Portuguese|newspaper=Jornal de Negócios|access-date=15 September 2017}}</ref>
In January and October 2010, many of the Apito Dourado [[telephone tapping|wiretaps]] were uploaded to [[YouTube]].<ref>{{cite news|last=|first=|date=3 October 2010|title=YouTube volta a revelar 'segredos' do futebol|trans-title=YouTube reveals football 'secrets' once again|url=http://www.cmjornal.xl.pt/detalhe/noticias/sport/desporto/youtube-volta-a-revelar-segredos-do-futebol|dead-url=yes|language=Portuguese|website=Correio da Manhã|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101005030731/http://www.cmjornal.xl.pt/detalhe/noticias/sport/desporto/youtube-volta-a-revelar-segredos-do-futebol|archive-date=5 October 2015|access-date=15 September 2017}}</ref>
==Chronology== {{Unreferenced section|date=September 2014}} On 20 April 2004, the Apito Dourado operation was triggered, leading to the arrest of 16 people, including club officials and referees. Among them were the then [[Portuguese League for Professional Football]] President and Mayor of [[Gondomar, Portugal|Gondomar]], [[Valentim Loureiro]], the then Chairman of the Refereeing Board, [[José António Pinto de Sousa]], and the then chairman of [[Gondomar S.C.]], [[José Luís Oliveira]].
On 2 December, the [[Polícia Judiciária|Judiciary Police]] was supposed to conduct a search at [[Jorge Nuno Pinto da Costa|Pinto da Costa]]'s home, but the Chairman of [[FC Porto]] had allegedly been previously informed by a source in the Judiciary Police, clearing the site beforehand. On the next day, Pinto da Costa presented himself willingly in the Court of Gondomar for questioning, and was released on a 200,000 euro bail.
On 20 April 2005, the "fruit affair", named as such because of the "fruit" (a codeword for prostitutes) which was used in tapped phone calls, involving FC Porto's chairman Pinto da Costa offering prostitutes to referee [[Jacinto Paixão]] before the match between FC Porto and [[C.F. Estrela da Amadora|Estrela da Amadora]], was dropped.
In January 2006, the Apito Dourado affair proceeded in Gondomar, and the public prosecution filed charges against 27 people, including Valentim Loureiro, José Oliveira and Pinto de Sousa.
By December, [[Carolina Salgado]], former partner of Pinto da Costa, published the book ''[[Eu, Carolina]]'' ("Me, Carolina"), in which she revealed new data about the case, mainly sports corruption situations, tax fraud, breach of judicial secrecy, assaults, perjury and obstruction to justice. This caused the court to reopen several court cases.
The court cases related to the FC Porto - Estrela da Amadora and [[S.C. Beira-Mar|Beira-Mar]] - FC Porto were reopened in early 2007. The first match involved FC Porto allegedly offering prostitutes to Jacinto Paixão (the referee); the second match involved Pinto da Costa allegedly delivering [[Augusto Duarte]] (the referee) an envelope containing 2,500 euro in order for him to benefit FC Porto. The affair became known as the "envelope affair".
In March 2007, the judiciary team responsible for the Apito Dourado affair announced that 56 inquiries were underway. In July, judge [[Maria José Morgado]] revealed that 20 charges were produced.
In March 2008, FC Porto was indicted for the corruption cases in the matches against Beira-Mar and Estrela da Amadora. For the same reason, [[C.D. Nacional|Nacional]] and [[Boavista F.C.|Boavista]] were also indicted for bribering the referees of the matches against [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] and [[C.S. Marítimo|Marítimo]], and the match against Estrela da Amadora, respectively.
In October 2008, the court filed the case against Pinto da Costa, Augusto Duarte, [[Rui Alves]] and [[António Araújo (referee)|António Araújo]] regarding the Nacional - Benfica match.
In March, the public prosecution asked for the conviction of Pinto da Costa, António Araújo and Augusto Duarte regarding the FC Porto - Beira-Mar match.
==Criminal court decisions== {{Unreferenced section|date=September 2014}} In June 2007, 13 of the 24 suspects in the Gondomar part of the affair, mainly related to lower division football, were convicted of charges comprising corruption, influence peddling and abuse of power. Valentim Loureiro was sentenced to three years and two months of suspended penalty for abuse of power, and lost his position of mayor of Gondomar. José Luís Oliveira, chairman of Gondomar SC and vice-chairman of the city of Gondomar was found guilty of 25 crimes of abuse of power and 10 crimes of corruption, and was sentenced to three years of suspended penalty. Pinto de Sousa was found guilty of 25 crimes of abuse of power and convicted to three years of suspended penalty.
João Macedo, António Eustáquio, Jorge Saramago (all three of them referees) were sentenced to pay a fine. The court considered proven that all three of them had received gold objects but that did not mean that the referees had breached the rules of the game of football association. It also stated that it was impossible to prove in which situation of a match the referee was acting intentionally in case of error.
Barbosa da Cunha, João Soares Mesquita, Ricardo Pinto, Carlos Carvalho, Valente Mendes, José Manuel Rodrigues, Sérgio Sedas, José Agostinho Silva and Leonel Viana were all acquitted by the Gondomar court.
On 3 April 2009, Pinto da Costa was acquitted on all criminal charges related to the Beira-Mar-FC Porto match of the 2003–04 season.
==Apito Final== {{Refimprove section|date=September 2014}} In 2007, the Portuguese League of Football started a non-criminal process calling it ''Apito Final'' (Final Whistle). On 9 May 2008, Boavista were relegated to the second-tier [[Segunda Liga|Liga de Honra]] for bribery and referee coercion and FC Porto were docked six points for attempted bribery. This caused [[UEFA]]'s Control and Disciplinary Body to ban FC Porto from the [[2008–09 UEFA Champions League]].<ref name="uefa ban"/> This decision was later annulled by UEFA's Appeals Body,<ref>{{cite news|date=17 June 2008|title=Porto admission confirmed|url=http://www.uefa.com/news/newsid=719886.html|website=UEFA|access-date=15 September 2017}}</ref> meaning FC Porto was admitted to the competition. The Portuguese League has also sentenced Pinto da Costa to a two-year suspension; [[João Loureiro]], Boavista's chairman and Valentim Loureiro's son, to a four-year suspension; and [[João Bartolomeu]], [[União de Leiria]] chairman, to a one-year suspension. Five referees have also been suspended.<ref>{{cite news|date=9 May 2008|title=Apito Final: Boavista punido com descida de divisão, FC Porto com perda de seis pontos|trans-title=Final Whistle: Boavista punished with league relegation, FC Porto punished with loss of six points|url=http://ultimahora.publico.clix.pt/noticia.aspx?id=1328267&idCanal=56|dead-url=yes|language=Portuguese|newspaper=[[Público (Portugal)|Público]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080621113108/http://ultimahora.publico.clix.pt/noticia.aspx?id=1328267&idCanal=56|archive-date=21 June 2008|access-date=15 September 2017}}</ref> All the clubs, chairmen, and referees punished filed appeals, except for FC Porto, whose punishment did not prevent them from winning the Portuguese League title.
On May 2011, the Central Administrative Court of the South of Portugal ruled that the decision of taking six points from FC Porto's global classification in the 2007–08 season, as well as the suspension of FC Porto's President, Jorge Nuno Pinto da Costa for two years, both confirmed in 2008 on a controversial meeting made by the Justice Council of the Portuguese Football Federation, were to be ruled as "inexistent", due to the fact that those decisions were taken by a small number of the remaining counselors, after the meeting had been declared finished by the Council's President, and acting behind the President's and the Vice-President's back, as they were absent by then. The Portuguese Football Federation has announced it would appeal from this decision to the Administrative Supreme Court.
Pinto da Costa was acquitted of corruption in relation to the match between FC Porto and Estrela da Amadora 2003–04 on 23 September 2014. The Justice Council (FPF) president acquitted the FC Porto president of "the practice of infringement disciplinary very serious corruption (...) in the form of trial."
Also Jacinto Paixão, at the date first category referee, was acquitted of the practice of "very serious disciplinary infraction of corruption of the refereeing team", along with the remaining technical team: José Carlos Gladim Chilrito and Manuel António Candeias Square.
The civil court considered the wiretaps as illegal in this process. Therefore, the Disciplinary Commission of the League, now the professional section of the Disciplinary Council of the Portuguese Football Federation, had to remove the wiretaps as evidence, stating "unproven" charges.
==Wiretaps== Several conversations between suspects were recorded during the Apito Dourado investigation, and many of them show talks about referee nominations and performances and alleged briberies. After the acquittal decisions, several wiretaps were released on YouTube and immediately went viral. Some of the most notorious ones include:
* A conversation (hours before the FC Porto-Estrela da Amadora match on 24 January 2004) between FC Porto's chairman, Pinto da Costa, and football agent António Araújo, in which Araújo asks for Pinto da Costa's authorization to send "fruit to sleep with" (an alleged codeword for prostitutes) to JP (alleged codename for Jacinto Paixão, the match referee). Pinto da Costa states in that conversation that "fruit" has already been sent.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Lx6Xz5rRuGY|title=Apito Dourado: 'Fruta para dormir'|date=22 January 2010|website=YouTube|language=Portuguese|trans-title=Apito Dourado: "Fruit for sleeping"|access-date=}}</ref> Four years later, a video recording emerged that showed a confession by Jacinto Paixão, in which he confesses to the usual practice of accepting prostitutes and paid trips to either benefit FC Porto (against [[Associação Académica de Coimbra – O.A.F.|Académica]]) or harm Benfica (against [[Moreirense F.C.|Moreirense]]). Jacinto Paixão states in the video that he recorded such confession in case something should happen to him or his family.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Kxkbrt1oR_o|title=Apito Dourado: Confissão de Jacinto Paixão|date=|website=YouTube|language=Portuguese|trans-title=Golden Whistle: Jacinto Paixão's confession|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|date=12 May 2011|title='FC Porto ofereceu-nos raparigas'|trans-title='FC Porto offered us girls'|url=https://desporto.sapo.pt/futebol/primeira_liga/artigo/2011/05/12/fc-porto-ofereceu-nos-raparigas|dead-url=yes|language=Portuguese|website=SAPO Desporto|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160402024735/http://desporto.sapo.pt/futebol/primeira_liga/artigo/2011/05/12/fc-porto-ofereceu-nos-raparigas|archive-date=2 April 2016|access-date=15 September 2017}}</ref> * Conversations between Pinto da Costa, António Araújo and Augusto Duarte (a referee), where the three arrange a meeting at Pinto da Costa's house. This took place two days before Augusto Duarte was refereeing the match between FC Porto and Beira-Mar.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XtqzgmhAOIk|title=Apito Dourado: António Araújo e Augusto Duarte|date=21 January 2010|website=YouTube|language=Portuguese|trans-title=Golden Whistle: Augusto Duarte and António Araújo|access-date=}}</ref> Pinto da Costa stated that this visit was due to the fact that the referee Augusto Duarte was seeking family advice from him. That the meeting had taken place was proven in court; however, the motive for it was not clear, so the charge was dismissed. * A conversation between [[C.F. Os Belenenses|Belenenses]] president, [[Sequeira Nunes]], and Pinto de Sousa, chairman of the Refereeing Board, which took place on 24 March 2004, where the former denounces to the latter that Nacional's president, Rui Alves, is offering prostitutes to Nacional's matches' referees in order to benefit Nacional. A month prior to that conversation, Rui Alves complains to António Araújo that Nacional has not won a match refereed by Augusto Duarte for a long time. Araújo then asks for Rui Alve's permission to "work" the referee in order to benefit Nacional against Benfica. Three days later, Araújo phones Alves to inform him that everything was in place.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-y7swlgm9lA|title=Pinto da Costa Novas Escutas 1|date=2 October 2010|website=YouTube|language=Portuguese|trans-title=Pinto da Costa New Wiretaps 1|access-date=}}</ref> Nacional won the match against Benfica (3–2).
==Aftermath== The Apito Dourado process was a major event in Portuguese football and made international headlines at the time. Pinto da Costa, the most notorious suspect, was not convicted by the criminal court system, although being convicted by the Portuguese League's disciplinary committee to a two-year ban. FC Porto was convicted by the league's disciplinary committee to a six-point loss and ordered to pay a €150,000 fine.<ref name="uefa ban"/>
Despite no heavy convictions of penalties, the scandal seriously damaged Portuguese football's and FC Porto's reputation. Santiago Segurola, [[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]'s assistant director stated in 2008, "It is terrible what is happening to football (...) In the last few years proven corruption cases have emerged from Italy and Portugal (...) There are people who want to win so much that they are willing to break the rules in the most obscene ways. One of the things that surprises the most is that they (the teams involved) are always the same: [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]], Porto..."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marca.com/charlas/santiagosegurola/12052008.html|title=Charlas|last=Segurola|first=Santiago|date=12 May 2008|website=Marca|language=Spanish|trans-title=Chats|access-date=15 September 2017|quote=Son casi siempre los mismos: Juventus, Oporto...}}</ref>
The Apito Dourado scandal not only hit Portuguese football but also the whole Portuguese criminal procedure system. One of the big controversies was the fact that the prosecutors had "no doubts" about the Judiciary Police tipping off Pinto da Costa to clear his office hours before the conduction of a search. However, since the source of the leak was unable to be identified, the accusation was dismissed.<ref>{{cite news|date=15 June 2007|title=Pinto da Costa avisado|trans-title=Pinto da Costa tipped off|url=http://www.cmjornal.xl.pt/detalhe/noticias/exclusivo-cm/pinto-da-costa-avisado|language=Portuguese|website=Correio da Manhã|access-date=15 September 2017}}</ref> The court decision which convicted lower division referees to fines has been subject of controversies. One of them is the justification it gave for not considering golden object offers to referees as relevant evidence. A wide debate has also been sparked between the right to privacy (invoked in this case as part of a claim that the unauthorized wiretaps were unusable evidence) and the demand for a more severe justice, regardless of the privacy rights of crime suspects.
The codewords used in the wiretaps have since become common Portuguese football jargon, expressions such as "''fruta para dormir''" ("fruit to sleep with", an alleged codeword for prostitutes), "dark coffee" and "latte" (referring to the skin tone of the prostitutes), "''rebuçado''" (literally translated as "candy") being used by both supporters and club officials to mock and attack clubs related to the Apito Dourado wiretaps, such as FC Porto, Boavista FC, CD Nacional and Gondomar SC.
[[CMTV]] started a series about Apito Dourado in 2013, regarding the 10th year anniversary of the scandal, by airing the already known wiretaps as well as releasing previously unknown ones.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qMkhEanpnps&list=PLfFPZiCPBl6e6JL6xhR7_PhXdxRk3-QHF|title=10 anos de Apito Dourado - Ep. 1 - Escutas Inéditas + Reportagem|date=2 April 2013|website=YouTube|language=Portuguese|trans-title=10 years of Golden Whistle - Ep. 1 - New Wiretaps|access-date=}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{cite book|last=Neves|first=Marinho|year=2007|title=Golpe de estádio: corrupção, prostituição e chantagem no mundo do futebol|trans-title=Stadium coup: corruption, prostitution and blackmail in the world of football|language=Portuguese|edition=3rd|location=Lisbon, Portugal|publisher=Terramar|isbn=978-972-710-131-3}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070805052325/http://dossiers.publico.pt/dossier.aspx?idCanal=1296 Apito Dourado news at ''Público''] (archived) {{pt icon}}

page.title: Battle of Santiago (1962 FIFA World Cup)

revision.text:
{{About|an association football match|real battles and other uses|Battle of Santiago (disambiguation){{!}}Battle of Santiago}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox football match | title = 1962 FIFA World Cup
Group 2 | image = [[File:Batalla de Santiago.jpg|frameless]] | caption = Italy's [[Giorgio Ferrini]] is removed from the pitch by [[Carabineros de Chile|Carabiniers of Chile]] policemen | event = | team1 = [[Chile national football team|Chile]] | team1association = {{flagicon|CHI|size=30px}} | team1score = 2 | team2 = [[Italy national football team|Italy]] | team2association = {{flagicon|ITA|size=30px}} | team2score = 0 | details = | date = 2 June 1962 | stadium = [[Estadio Nacional Julio Martínez Prádanos|Estadio Nacional]] | city = [[Santiago|Santiago de Chile]] | referee = [[Ken Aston]] ([[The Football Association|England]]) | attendance = 66,057 | weather = }} The '''Battle of Santiago''' ({{lang-it|Battaglia di Santiago}}, {{lang-es|Batalla de Santiago}}) was a [[football (soccer)|football]] match during the [[1962 FIFA World Cup]], played between host [[Chile national football team|Chile]] and [[Italy national football team|Italy]] on 2 June 1962 in [[Santiago de Chile|Santiago]].{{cite news | title=Battle of Santiago |first=Scott |last=Murray |date=6 November 2003 |newspaper=The Guardian |url=http://football.guardian.co.uk/news/theknowledge/0,,1079146,00.html |accessdate=26 June 2006 |location=London}} It gained its nickname from the level of violence seen in the game, in which two players were sent off, numerous punches were thrown and police intervention was required four times. The referee was [[Ken Aston]], who later went on to invent [[Penalty card|yellow and red cards]].{{cite web |url=https://www.fifa.com/aboutfifa/developing/refereeing/news/newsid=80623.html |title=Ken Aston – the inventor of yellow and red cards |date=15 January 2002 |website=FIFA.com |accessdate=21 October 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080606022246/http://www.fifa.com/aboutfifa/developing/refereeing/news/newsid=80623.html |archivedate=6 June 2008}} ==Background== In this Group 2 clash, already heightened tensions between the two football teams were exacerbated by the description of [[Santiago, Chile|Santiago]] in crude terms by two Italian journalists, Antonio Ghirelli and Corrado Pizzinelli; they had written that Santiago was a backwater dump where "the phones don't work, taxis are as rare as faithful husbands, a cable to Europe costs an arm and a leg and a letter takes five days to turn up", and its population as prone to "malnutrition, illiteracy, alcoholism and poverty. Chile is a small, proud and poor country: it has agreed to organise this World Cup in the same way as Mussolini agreed to send our air force to bomb London (they didn't arrive). The capital city has 700 hotel beds. Entire neighbourhoods are given over to open prostitution. This country and its people are proudly miserable and backwards."{{cite web |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HV4i32LWwXwC&pg=PA115&lpg=PA115&dq=chile+vs+italy+1962+the+phones+don't+work&source=bl&ots=MWOr6wyJs_&sig=cL7nHArEs1EzgvJyNnx9wouobL0&hl=en&sa=X&ei=G8WaVdm0MYSz-AHdsYHQBQ&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=chile+vs+italy+1962+the+phones+don't+work&f=false |title=How to Win the World Cup |first=Graham |last=McColl |date=10 June 2010 |publisher=Random House |isbn=978-1-4070-5732-3 |page=115 |accessdate=21 October 2017 |via=Google Books}} Chilean newspapers fired back, describing Italians in general as fascists, mafiosos, oversexed, and, because some of Inter Milan's players had recently been involved in a doping scandal, drug addicts.{{cite web |url=http://www.ussoccerplayers.com/the-battle-of-santiago |title=The Battle of Santiago |first=Ken |last=Pendleton |date=16 March 2007 |website=US Soccer Players |accessdate=21 October 2017}} The journalists involved were forced to flee the country, while an Argentinian scribe mistaken for an Italian in a Santiago bar was beaten up and hospitalised. Chile's organisation of and preparation for the tournament had been severely disrupted by the [[1960 Valdivia earthquake]], the strongest earthquake ever recorded in human history. Articles in the Italian papers ''La Nazione'' and ''Corriere della Sera'' were saying that allowing Chile to host the World Cup was "pure madness"; this was used and magnified by local newspapers to inflame the Chilean population. The British newspaper the Daily Express wrote "The tournament shows every sign of developing into a violent bloodbath. Reports read like battlefront despatches. Italy vs Germany was described as 'wrestling and warfare'". ==Match== ===Summary=== The first foul occurred within 12 seconds of kick-off. Italy's [[Giorgio Ferrini]] was sent off in the twelfth minute after a foul on [[Honorino Landa]], but refused to leave the pitch and had to be dragged off by policemen. English referee [[Ken Aston]] did not see a punch by Chilean [[Leonel Sánchez]] to Italian [[Mario David]], which had come in retaliation for being fouled seconds earlier. When David attempted to kick Sánchez in the head a few minutes later (he missed), he was sent off. In the violence that continued, Sánchez broke [[Humberto Maschio]]'s nose with a left hook, but Aston did not send him off. The two teams engaged in scuffles and spitting, and police had to intervene three more times. Chile won the match 2–0. When highlights from the match were shown on British television a couple of days later (not the same night, because film of matches had to be flown back to the UK), the match was introduced by BBC sports commentator [[David Coleman]] as "the most stupid, appalling, disgusting and disgraceful exhibition of football, possibly in the history of the game." ===Details=== {{#lst:1962 FIFA World Cup Group 2|2-3}} {{#lst:1962 FIFA World Cup Group 2|Lineups 2-3}} ==See also== *[[Battle of Highbury]] *[[Battle of Berne (1954 FIFA World Cup)|Battle of Berne]] *[[Battle of Bordeaux (1938 FIFA World Cup)|Battle of Bordeaux]] *[[Battle of Bramall Lane]] *[[Battle of Nuremberg (2006 FIFA World Cup)|Battle of Nuremberg]] *[[Football War]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ezGiDKbC9q8 Video of the match in full length] *{{cite web |url=http://www.ultimathule.it/modules.php?name=Content&pa=showpage&pid=153 |title=La battaglia di Santiago |website=ultimathule.it |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071009230200/http://www.ultimathule.it/modules.php?name=Content&pa=showpage&pid=153 |archivedate=9 October 2007 |language=it}} *{{cite web |url=http://www.todoslosmundiales.com.ar/mundiales/1962chile/historias/0017chilevsitalia.htm |title=Chile vs Italia, Todavía no Existía el Premio Fair Play |website=todoslosmundiales.com.ar |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070425193734/http://www.todoslosmundiales.com.ar/mundiales/1962chile/historias/0017chilevsitalia.htm |archivedate=25 April 2007 |language=es}} {{1962 FIFA World Cup}} {{Chile national football team matches}} {{Italy national football team matches}} __NOTOC__ [[Category:1962 FIFA World Cup]] [[Category:Chile national football team matches|1962]] [[Category:Italy national football team matches|1962]] [[Category:FIFA World Cup matches]] [[Category:Brawls in team sports]] [[Category:Chile–Italy relations]] [[Category:Italy at the 1962 FIFA World Cup]] [[Category:FIFA World Cup controversies]]

{{unreferenced|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = Blofib| image = | fullname = Blofib| nickname = | founded = | ground = Blofib Terra
Catio, [[Guinea-Bissau]]| capacity = 5,000| chairman = | league = Campeonato Assotiation da Guine-Bissau | season = 2007/08 | position = | }} '''Blofib''' is a [[Guinea-Bissau]]an [[football (soccer)|football]] club based in [[Catio]]. They play in the 2 division in Guinean football, the [[Campeonato Nacional da Guine-Bissau]]. {{Campeonato Nacional da Guine-Bissau}} [[Category:Football clubs in Guinea-Bissau|Blofib]] {{GuineaBissau-footyclub-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Robert Churchill McConnell''' (January 18, 1925 – March 18, 2012) was a founding member of the [[Society for American Baseball Research]] (SABR), serving as its secretary and treasurer. In 1985, he won the first [[Bob Davids Award]], SABR's highest honor.<ref>[http://sabr.org/about/bob-davids-award Bob Davids Award winners]</ref>
==Early life== McConnell was born on January 18, 1925 in [[Seattle, Washington]], though he moved around continuously throughout his youth. His family settled in [[Newark, New Jersey]] in 1935.
He joined the [[United States Navy|Navy]] in 1942, serving on the U.S.S. Whitman and U.S.S. Mifflin during his first three years in the service. He was sent for officer training at [[Vanderbilt University]] in July 1945, whence he earned a [[Bachelor of Science]] in mechanical engineering in 1949.<ref name=SABRbio>[http://sabr.org/bioproj/person/5e8e335e SABR Biography]</ref>
==Baseball research endeavors== McConnell is credited with finding, filling in and fixing considerable amounts of missing, incomplete or incorrect historical baseball information, especially that concerning home runs.<ref name=SABRbio /> His work largely included seeking out old box scores, gleaning statistics and details from those, his new findings and sharing them with other baseball research enthusiasts - many of whom would be among the founding SABR members. Considered an expert on home runs, he co-wrote the book ''The Home Run Encyclopedia''.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books/about/SABR_presents_the_home_run_encyclopedia.html?id=TNjtAAAAMAAJ Google Books]</ref> His expertise was cited by the ''[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]'', ''[[Associated Press]]'' and ''[[The Press of Atlantic City]]'', among others.<ref>[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=NewsLibrary&p_multi=APAB&d_place=APAB&p_theme=newslibrary2&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0F89220D1145B1D2&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM AP citing]</ref><ref>[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=AC&p_theme=ac&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EBE57ED2C9E548D&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM Press of Atlantic City]</ref><ref>[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SL&p_theme=sl&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB087229BEED282&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM Stl. Post-Dispatch]</ref>
He died on March 18, 2012 in [[Newark, Delaware]].
==References== <!-- Ext link LCCN cites presum. obituary "News journal (Wilmington, Del.), Mar. 20, 2012: p. B9" --> {{reflist}}
