{{refimprove|date=February 2014}} '''Hurling''' ({{lang-gle|Iománaíocht/Iomáint}}), the [[Gaelic games|Gaelic sport]], is a prominent feature '''in popular culture'''.
==In film== Hurling and [[Hollywood]] have long been linked.<ref name="hurlinghollywoodlink">Commins, Michael. [http://www.mayonews.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4835:hurling-and-the-hollywood-link-goes-way-back-in-time&Itemid=51 "Hurling and the Hollywood link"], ''Mayo News'', 26 August 2008.</ref> Several awards have resulted from the depiction of hurling in film, including the [[Palme d'Or]] and several [[Academy Award]] nominations:
* The 1930s [[Warner Brothers]] short film ''Sports Thrills'', narrated by CBS broadcaster [[Ted Husing]], demonstrated hurling.<ref name="hurlinghollywoodlink"/> * A 1936 [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer|MGM]]-commissioned short series, directed by David Miller, portrayed hurling as "bordering on savage" with "all the Hollywood stereo-type images of the Irish back then, short of drinking, on the field". The GAA complained and attempted to have some of the more unpleasant scenes removed.<ref name="hurlinghollywoodlink"/> * The 1952 film ''[[The Quiet Man]]'' features the famous line: "Sure don't you know the [[Mayo GAA|Mayo]] hurlers haven't been beaten west of the [[River Shannon|Shannon]] in the last 20 years."<ref name="hurlinghollywoodlink"/> * A 1955 [[Paramount Studios]]-commissioned short film, Three Kisses,<ref name="NUIG">National University of Ireland, Galway [http://www.nuigalway.ie/about-us/news-and-events/news-archive/2010/august2010/recently-discovered-hurling-films-screened-for-first-time-in-eighty-years-1.html "Recently Discovered Hurling Films Screened for First Time in Eighty Years"], ''NUI Galway'', 5 August 2010</ref> directed by Justin Herman, was nominated for an Academy Award.<ref name="hurlinghollywoodlink"/> * The 1956 film ''[[The Rising of the Moon]]'' featured a badly bruised and bandaged but victorious local hurling team, leading to "deep concern" about Hollywood's tendency to overdo the bad side of hurling.<ref name="hurlinghollywoodlink"/> Novelist [[Flann O'Brien]] (''[[The Third Policeman]]'', ''[[At Swim-Two-Birds]]'') gave the disagreement a satirical edge in his newspaper column.<ref name="hurlinghollywoodlink"/> * During filming of the 1958 Rank Studios film ''Rooney'' titular actor John Gregson ran out onto the [[Croke Park]] turf with the teams ahead of the 1957 All-Ireland Senior Championship Final between [[Kilkenny GAA|Kilkenny]] and [[Waterford GAA|Waterford]]. He wore a Kilkenny jersey to film the part.<ref name="hurlinghollywoodlink"/> * The 2006 [[Ken Loach]] film ''[[The Wind That Shakes the Barley (film)|The Wind That Shakes the Barley]]'', set in 1920, opens with a Sunday hurling match in [[County Cork]].<ref>McBride, Dara. [http://www.irishcentral.com/ent/Top-10-Irish-films-of-the-decade--79490672.html "Top 10 Irish films of the decade"]. IrishCentral.com. Thursday, 17 December 2009.</ref> The film won the [[Palme d'Or]] at the [[2006 Cannes Film Festival]]. *In the opening scenes of the 2011 film ''[[Blitz (film)|Blitz]]'', [[Jason Statham]] uses a hurley to beat up three youths who are trying to steal a car. Statham's character is heard to say, "This, lads, is a hurley, used in the Irish game of hurling, a cross between hockey and murder". *In the Disney production "Secret of Boyne Castle" 1972 - episode 1, Kurt Russell was playing Hurling at the boarding school where the mini series starts.
==In literature==
* ''[[The Hurley Maker's Son]]'' - a memoir by Patrick Deeley, which takes an in-depth look at the craft of hurley making during the author's childhood in a small townland in Galway - was shortlisted for the Irish Book Awards in 2016. * Hurling is referenced in the works of [[James Joyce]]; he mentions it in ''[[A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man]]'' (1916)<ref>Joyce, James. [https://books.google.com/books?id=_ILE9B-c6uUC&pg=PA210&lpg=PA210&dq=hurling+james+joyce&source=bl&ots=KJ-7Mugswj&sig=xTycCtddEKTBp_cbS9_VnCxcocQ&hl=en&ei=6l0qTdGnIMq5hAeAkZyhDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CCcQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q&f=false ''A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man''].</ref> and ''[[Ulysses (novel)|Ulysses]]'' (1922).<ref>[http://www.thewildgeese.com/pages/cusack2.html "Michael Cusack and James Joyce: Pair May Well Have Reshaped Modern Ireland"].</ref> * [[Samuel Beckett]]'s novel ''[[Murphy (novel)|Murphy]]'' references hurling.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=2yWK_FHbkrIC&pg=PA47&lpg=PA47&dq=hurling+samuel+beckett&source=bl&ots=VCBeFXiPZ0&sig=sGJomZT4Vm1gnykktHL1CK9wCP8&hl=en&ei=lmEqTdjpKMaJhQfFne3-AQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q&f=false "Samuel Beckett—humanistic perspectives"]. Morris Beja, S. E. Gontarski, Pierre A. G. Astier, Ohio State University. College of Humanities.</ref> * In [[John Banville]]'s novel ''[[The Newton Letter]]'', the character Edward "appeared, brandishing a hurley stick", which he later "leaned on, [...] admiring his drink" before taking it up again after urinating against a chestnut tree. "Still held dangled down" by the narrator's side, Edward then proceeds to "gently bat" him with the hurley stick.<ref>Banville, John. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Pf15hdEyX3wC&pg=PA38&lpg=PA38&dq=banville+newton+letter+hurley+stick&source=bl&ots=4COJCAHTPH&sig=EVDjnW0g7lZn9xwO3412TtOK2EM&hl=en&sa=X&ei=WTsTVZadO-LT7QaQwYGgDA&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=banville%20newton%20letter%20hurley%20stick&f=false ''The Newton Letter''].</ref> * The [[Colm Tóibín]] novel ''[[Brooklyn (novel)|Brooklyn]]'' (2009) features an exchange between two characters involving the confusion that may occur when discussing the similarities between hurling and the American sport of [[baseball]].<ref>Tóibín, Colm. [https://books.google.com/books?id=4mOrEoLlJQMC&pg=PA169&lpg=PA169&dq=hurling+Colm+T%C3%B3ib%C3%ADn&source=bl&ots=MBdMTcURjB&sig=LpIuHTQqFeN7WtvCu6t3mpNRRZU&hl=en&ei=l2sqTdmkDZKKhQeKicHmAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Brooklyn''].</ref> * [[Stephen Maturin]] in [[Patrick O'Brian]]'s [[Aubrey-Maturin series]] was a hurler, and demonstrates his skills to the dismay of his cricket teammates in one of the books. * In [[Walter Macken]]'s novel ''Rain on the Wind'', one of his Irish trilogy, a game of hurling takes place, and the history and background to the game is explained; however, a player gets injured in the course of the game. * The [[Eoin Colfer]] novel ''[[Benny and Omar]]'' (1998) is about a young hurler named Benny who moves from Ireland to [[Tunisia]]. * [[Hugo Hamilton (writer)|Hugo Hamilton]]'s book ''The Speckled People'' (2003) contains numerous references to hurling which he uses to come to terms with Irish and German history.<ref>Hamilton, Hugo. [http://www.powells.com/essays/hamilton.html "Speaking to the Walls in English"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060501181529/http://www.powells.com/essays/hamilton.html |date=2006-05-01 }}. "I remember a school teacher relating Irish history as a hurling match where our team was losing but won the match in the last minute. I remember my mother saying that German history was a very brutal hurling match."</ref>
==In music== * A "hurley ball" is referenced in [[The Pogues]]' song The Broad Majestic Shannon: "A rusty tin can and an old hurley ball." The song appears on [[If I Should Fall From Grace With God]] LP, and was written by front man [[Shane MacGowan]]. * [[Bruce Springsteen]] is a hurling fan and follows [[Limerick GAA|Limerick]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thescore.thejournal.ie/hurling-fan-bruce-springsteen-dedicates-glory-days-to-limericks-munster-heroes-996282-Jul2013/|title=Hurling fan Bruce Springsteen dedicates Glory Days to Limerick’s Munster heroes|work=The Score|date=18 June 2013|accessdate=18 June 2013}}</ref>
==In television== * [[Doug Ross]], the character played by [[George Clooney]] in ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]'', mentioned planning to watch "Irish hurling" in a season one episode. This has been described as "hurling's biggest pop culture moment ever."<ref>McDaniel, Xavier. [http://www.balls.ie/gaa/random-the-er-episode-where-george-clooney-talks-about-watching-irish-hurling/#sthash.3EhSoTHC.dpbs "The ER Episode Where George Clooney Talks About Watching ‘Irish Hurling’"], 27 March 2012.</ref> * The Irish language version of ''[[Cheers]]'', ''Teach Seán'', substitutes hurling in place of [[baseball]] as the main character's former sport.<ref>{{cite news|first=Hillary|last=Busis|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2012/12/19/irish-cheers/|title=Irish language adaptation of 'Cheers' is in development|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=19 December 2012|accessdate=19 December 2012}}</ref> * The male members of the Dillon family, [[Tommy Dillon|Tommy]] and [[Zak Dillon|Zak]], in ''[[Fair City]]'' display an interest in hurling. When they first arrive from Kilkenny a storyline revolves around Zak's determination to play rugby instead of his father's favourite sport, hurling. * In a popular Guinness Beer Commercial, shown in the US, Ireland, and the UK, made in 2007, had a player preparing for a Free as the last play of the game, the opposing sides were lined up, and in the build-up before the shot, the player experiences nervousness imagines the ball become a cement cube, and the men at the goal looking like orcs with shields in front of him. upon the announcer saying what would inspire the player, it shows the bartender putting down a freshly poured pint of Guinness beer at an Irish Pub, as the <ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZoPM4RwOCW8 Guinness]</ref> going from cloudly gold to clear black, the player growing confident makes the play, and strikes the ball, and the words 'believe' appear at the end of the commercial, leaving the ending of whether he made a goal or not ambiguous
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{for|museum located in Iowa City|University of Iowa Athletics Hall of Fame}} {{ref improve|date=January 2017}} The '''Iowa Sports Hall of Fame''', sponsored by the ''[[Des Moines Register]]'', honors outstanding [[sportsperson|athlete]]s and sports contributors. To be eligible, members must have either been born in [[Iowa]] or gained prominence while competing for a college or university in Iowa.
Leighton Housh, former executive [[sports journalism|sports editor]] of the Register, established the [[Hall of Fame]] in 1951. Twenty-four athletes were chosen in the inangural class. The Hall of Fame now includes more than 170 athletes from 20 sports. Inductees are chosen by veteran members of the Register's sports department.
==Partial list of inductees== ===Football=== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * 1951 - [[Jay Berwanger]] * 1951 - [[Aubrey Devine]] * 1951 - [[Nile Kinnick]] * 1951 - [[Elmer Layden]] * 1951 - [[Duke Slater]] * 1956 - [[Clyde Williams (football)|Clyde Williams]] * 1958 - [[Gordon Locke]] * 1959 - [[Billy Edson]] * 1961 - [[Joe Laws]] * 1962 - [[Eddie Anderson (football coach)|Eddie Anderson]] * 1970 - [[Johnny Bright]] * 1971 - [[Cal Jones]] * 1973 - [[Willis Glassgow]] * 1975 - [[Emlen Tunnell]] * 1976 - [[Randy Duncan]] * 1977 - [[Alex Karras]] * 1980 - [[Don Perkins]] * 1983 - [[Mike Enich]] * 1985 - [[Paul Krause]] * 1986 - [[Ed Podolak]] * 1987 - [[Wally Hilgenberg]] * 1989 - [[Forest Evashevski]] * 1998 - [[Roger Craig (American football)|Roger Craig]] * 1999 - [[Matt Blair]] * 2000 - [[Larry Station]] * 2001 - [[Chuck Long]] * 2002 - [[Ken Ploen]] * 2002 - [[Chad Hennings]] * 2003 - [[Reggie Roby]] * 2006 - [[Andre Tippett]] * 2012 - [[Marv Levy]] * 2013 - [[Tavian Banks]] * 2014 - [[Tim Dwight]] {{div col end}}
===Basketball=== * 1951 - [[Murray Wier]] * 1980 - [[Carl Cain]] * 1983 - [[Don Nelson]] * 1990 - [[Fred Brown (basketball)|Fred Brown]] * 1993 - [[John Johnson (basketball)|John Johnson]] * 1994 - [[Ronnie Lester]] * 1999 - [[Bobby Hansen]]
===Baseball=== [[File:George Stone baseball card.jpg|thumb|right|180px|[[George Stone (outfielder)|George Stone]]]] * 1951 - [[Cap Anson|"Cap" Anson]] * 1951 - [[Fred Clarke]] * 1951 - [[Red Faber|"Red" Faber]] * 1951 - [[Bob Feller]] * 1952 - [[Dazzy Vance|"Dazzy" Vance]] * 1954 - [[Dave Bancroft]] * 1956 - [[Jack Coombs|"Jack" Coombs]] * 1961 - [[Bing Miller|"Bing" Miller]] * 1962 - [[Hank Severeid]] * 1963 - [[Earl Whitehill]] * 1965 - [[Hal Trosky]] * 1968 - [[Cal McVey]] * 1970 - [[George Stone (outfielder)|George Stone]], batting champion * 1976 - [[George Pipgras]] * 1984 - [[Chet Brewer]] * 1988 - [[Jack Dittmer]] * 2000 - [[Mike Boddicker]]
===Other sports===
* 1951 - [[Farmer Burns|"Farmer" Burns]], wrestling * 1951 - [[Sabin Carr]], track and field * 1951 - [[Welker Cochran]], billiards * 1951 - [[Frank Gotch]], wrestling * 1951 - [[George Saling]], track and field * 1951 - [[Morgan Taylor]], track and field * 1952 - [[Earl Caddock]], wrestling * 1959 - [[Harris Coggeshall]], tennis * 1963 - [[Ray Conger]], track and field * 1972 - [[Garfield Wood]], speedboat racing * 1972 - [[Jack Fleck]], golf * 1973 - [[Frank Wykoff]], track and field * 1981 - [[Doreen Wilber]], archery * 1981 - [[Dan Gable]], wrestling * 1982 - [[Caitlyn Jenner|Bruce Jenner]], track and field * 1990 - [[Tiny Lund|"Tiny" Lund]], auto racing * 1993 - [[Francis Cretzmeyer]], track and field * 1993 - [[Chris Taylor (wrestler)|Chris Taylor]], wrestling * 1994 - [[Nawal El Moutawakel]], track and field * 1997 - [[Judy Kimball]], golf * 2003 - [[Danny Harris]], track * 2012 - [[Cael Sanderson]], wrestling
==See also== *[[Glen Brand Wrestling Hall of Fame of Iowa]] *[[Iowa State University Athletics Hall of Fame]] *[[University of Iowa Athletics Hall of Fame]]

Cline of [[CSHQA]]
[[Boise, Idaho]] {{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=By1OAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Se0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=4964%2C3440790 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |title=Emerick Co. to complete Idaho roof |agency=Associated Press |date=November 23, 1974 |page=14}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wcdeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QTIMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4080,6154858 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=Idaho |title=Kibbie Dome leaks bring suit |last=Moulton |first=Kristen |date=June 30, 1981 |page=1A}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iwNMAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WvkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2541,297783 |newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle |location=Washington |title=Lawsuit springs from dome's leak |last=Carrier |first=Rebecca |date=July 1, 1981 |page=3}} | main_contractors = Emerick Construction Co.
[[Portland, Oregon]] | former_names = Idaho Stadium (1971–74) | tenants = [[Idaho Vandals]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]])
(1971–present) – [[Idaho Vandals football|football]]

[[Idaho Vandals men's basketball|Basketball]]: 7,000
(Cowan Spectrum) |record_attendance = 19,878
vs. [[Boise State–Idaho football rivalry|Boise State]] on

vs. [[Montana Grizzlies basketball|Montana]] on
February 12, [[Don Monson#1982–83 season|1983]]}} {{Location map |USA |relief = 1 |label = Moscow |lat = 46.726 |long = -117.017 |caption = Location in the United States |marksize = 5 |float = |background = |width = 250 }} {{Location map |USA Idaho |relief = 1 |label = Moscow |lat = 46.726 |long = -116.95 |caption = Location in [[Idaho]] |marksize = 5 |float = |background = |width = 170 }} The '''William H. Kibbie-ASUI Activity Center''' (commonly known as the '''Kibbie Dome''') is a multi-purpose indoor athletic [[stadium]] in the [[Pacific Northwest|northwest]] United States, on the campus of the [[University of Idaho]] in [[Moscow, Idaho]]. It is the home of the [[Idaho Vandals]] and is used for intercollegiate competition in four sports: [[Idaho Vandals football|football]], [[Idaho Vandals men's basketball|basketball]], [[tennis]], and indoor [[athletics (track and field)|track & field]]. The Kibbie Dome opened {{Time ago|1971}} as an outdoor [[concrete]] football stadium in October [[1971 Idaho Vandals football team|1971]],{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=aIBfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WTAMAAAAIBAJ&pg=6240%2C2361152 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=Idaho |title=Under construction: architect's drawing |agency=photo |date=June 11, 1971 |page=18}} built on the same site of the demolished wooden [[Neale Stadium]] ([[1937 Idaho Vandals football team|1937]]–68), seen in this early 1950s [http://www.tomandrodna.com/Stadium.jpg photo]. Following the [[1974 Idaho Vandals football team|1974]] football season, a barrel-arched roof and vertical end walls were added in ten months and the stadium re-opened as an enclosed facility in September [[1975 Idaho Vandals football team|1975]]. With just 16,000 permanent seats,{{cite web|title=Kibbie-ASUI Activity Center|publisher=University of Idaho Athletics|accessdate=October 11, 2017|ref=http://www.govandals.com/facilities/?id=1|quote=The facility has a capacity of more than 16,000.}} it was the second smallest home stadium for [[college football]] in [[Football Bowl Subdivision|Division I FBS]] (formerly Division I-A), but Idaho football has rejoined the FCS and is a member of the Big Sky Conference. Since February 2001, the Kibbie Dome has been reconfigured for basketball games and is referred to as the '''Cowan Spectrum''', seating 7,000. The [[elevation]] of the playing surface is {{convert|2610|ft|}} above [[sea level]].[http://terraserver.homeadvisor.msn.com/image.aspx?T=2&S=12&Z=11&X=623&Y=6468&W=2&qs=%7cMoscow%7cIdaho%7c Terraserver.homeadvisor.msn.com] – topo map – UI campus – accessed 2009-09-17 ==History== ===Construction=== The stadium was built in stages and took several years to complete. Originally, the new football stadium was to be outdoors and seat over 23,000 spectators, with an adjacent 10,000-seat indoor arena for basketball. The [[Big West|PCAA]] conference had been launched in 1969 and Idaho was attempting to join, but political wrangling in the state legislature and subsequent budget cuts caused a change in the scope of the stadium project. This ensured that Idaho could not make the move to the PCAA; the Vandals remained in the [[Big Sky Conference]] with the other state schools, [[Idaho State University|Idaho State]] and new member [[Boise State University|Boise State]].[http://www.uiargonaut.com/content/view/3661/48/ UI Argonaut] By the time Idaho finally did join the PCAA in 1996, the conference had changed its name to the Big West. The revised plan was for a smaller capacity football stadium, to be enclosed to allow use as a basketball arena (and indoor track and tennis as well). This multi-purpose concept had been recently used at [[Idaho State University|Idaho State]] in [[Pocatello, Idaho|Pocatello]], where the [[Minidome]] (now [[Holt Arena]]) had opened in 1970. Construction on the concrete grandstands started in February 1971,[http://www.lib.uidaho.edu/special-collections/uibldngs.html#K lib.uidaho.edu/special-collections/uibldngs.html#K] after a fire destroyed the previously condemned wooden [[Neale Stadium]] in November [[1969 Idaho Vandals football team|1969]].[http://www.lib.uidaho.edu/special-collections/uibldngs.html#N lib.uidaho.edu/special-collections/uibldngs.html#N] The stadium, which opened in [[1937 Idaho Vandals football team|1937]], had been condemned in August 1969 due to soil erosion beneath the grandstands. The Vandal football team played its limited home schedule for the next two seasons at [[Washington State University|WSU's]] [[Rogers Field (Washington State)|Rogers Field]] in [[Pullman, Washington|Pullman]]. After a fire significantly damaged Rogers Field's south grandstand in April 1970, WSU moved all of its [[1970 Washington State Cougars football team|1970]] and [[1971 Washington State Cougars football team|1971]] home games to [[Joe Albi Stadium]] in [[Spokane, Washington|Spokane]], but the Vandals remained at Rogers in Pullman for four "home" games in [[1970 Idaho Vandals football team|1970]]. The Vandals' game with WSU on September 19 in Spokane was dubbed the {{nowrap|"Displaced Bowl."[http://washingtonstate.scout.com/2/243292.html washingtonstate.scout.com/2/243292.html] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131002011344/http://washingtonstate.scout.com/2/243292.html |date=2013-10-02 }}}} A lopsided {{nowrap|44–16 win}} for the Cougars, it was WSU's only victory in a stretch of 22 games. Back in Moscow, weather-related construction delays in the spring put the new "Idaho Stadium" a month behind {{nowrap|schedule.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=epBfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yzAMAAAAIBAJ&pg=6181%2C5519292 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=(Idaho) |title=Idaho officials told stadium will be ready |date=August 27, 1971 |page=17}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=XKdYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=j_gDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7291%2C4492697 |newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle |location=(Washington) |title=Work pace brisk on new Idaho football plant |agency=photos |date=September 30, 1971 |page=29}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=PCxOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=v-wDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7476,2801236 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=(Spokane, Washington) |title=Real homecoming |date=October 8, 1971 |page=27}}}} The Vandals played their first two "home" games in [[1971 Idaho Vandals football team|1971]] well away from campus, in Boise for the opener and Spokane two weeks later. Uncompleted, the stadium debuted on October 9 with a {{nowrap|40–3}} victory over [[Idaho State Bengals football|Idaho State]] {{nowrap|before 14,200;}} {{nowrap|it was the}} first football game on campus in nearly {{nowrap|three years.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rJFYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ZPgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5859,2668148 |newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle |location=(Washington) |title=Idaho likes home play |last=Wakeley |first=Dan |date=October 11, 1971 |page=15}}}} The Vandals went {{nowrap|8–3}} in 1971, which included a school-record eight-game winning streak, and won the [[Big Sky Conference|Big Sky]] title. For its first four seasons (1971–74), the stadium was outdoors and {{nowrap|without lights.{{cite web |url=https://digital.lib.uidaho.edu/cdm/singleitem/collection/pg1/id/1160/rec/46 |work=University of Idaho Library |agency=(Digital Initiatives) |title=University of Idaho campuses, oblique aerial view. [3-50] |date=1972 |accessdate=August 20, 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://issuu.com/uidahodigital/docs/gem1973/26 |publisher=''Gem of the Mountains'', University of Idaho yearbook |title=Football: 1972 season |date=1973 |page=23}}}} In the summer of [[1972 Idaho Vandals football team|1972]], a [[Tartan Turf]] field was installed over a {{convert|4|in|cm|adj=on|spell=in}} asphalt {{nowrap|bed,}} with a roll-up mechanism behind the west end zone; the one-piece field was the first in the {{nowrap|world.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=G2cfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0tQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2265,6368555 |newspaper=Southeast Missourian |location=(Cape Girardeau) |title=Football field rolls up |date=February 22, 1973 |page=12}}}} In November [[1974 Idaho Vandals football team|1974]], approval was finally granted by the board of regents to enclose {{nowrap|the stadium.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NpdfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=RDEMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5327%2C2432627 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=(Idaho) |title=Regents OK stadium roof |last=Martin |first=Vicki |date=November 11, 1974 |page=9}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=RJdfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=RDEMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1883%2C6153938 |work=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=(Idaho) |title=Roof contract awarded |agency=Associated Press |date=November 23, 1974 |page=1B}}}} {{nowrap|The arched roof}} and vertical end walls were completed in time for the [[1975 Idaho Vandals football team|1975]] season's home opener on September 27, a deflating {{nowrap|14–29 loss}} to Idaho State in front {{nowrap|of 14,079.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rKVfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=RDIMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5811%2C8544083 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=(Idaho) |last=Emerson |first=Paul |title=Early ISU burst brings down roof on Vandal debut |date=September 28, 1975 |page=B1}}}} The enclosed stadium was renamed that year for '''William H. Kibbie''', a construction executive from [[Salt Lake City]] and a primary benefactor of the project; he contributed $300,000 in 1974 to initiate the funding drive.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EqNYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=nPgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2173%2C2958100 |newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle |location=Washington |title=University of Idaho gets $300,000 for roof |date=November 9, 1974 |page=2}}[http://www.supportui.uidaho.edu/default.aspx?pid=24973#Kibbie supportui.uidaho.edu/default.aspx?pid=24973#Kibbie] Bill Kibbie (1918–1988),{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=fVNTAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PoQDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7260%2C4607976 |newspaper=Deseret News |location=Salt Lake City, Utah |agency=(obituary) |title=W.H. (Bill) Kibbie |date=February 13, 1988 |page=4B}}{{cite news |url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/88172110 |work=Find a Grave |title=William H. Kibbie |accessdate=October 16, 2016}} originally of [[Bellevue, Idaho|Bellevue]] in [[Blaine County, Idaho|Blaine County]], was a [[University of Idaho|UI]] student for less than a month in 1936 when he withdrew due to his {{nowrap|father's illness.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kU8tAAAAIBAJ&sjid=idAFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3628%2C2129821 |newspaper=Idahonian |location=(Moscow) |title=William Kibbie was a loyal friend of university |last=Bird |first=Kenyon |date=February 15, 1988 |page=4A}}[http://www.auxserv.uidaho.edu/default.aspx?pid=98990 auxserv.uidaho.edu/default.aspx?pid=98990]}} {{nowrap|He entered}} the construction business, then served as a [[Consolidated B-24 Liberator|B-24]] pilot in [[World War II]], and eventually headed JELCO (later EMKO), a major contracting company {{nowrap|in [[Utah]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=0KZCP5UExFUC&dat=19880212&printsec=frontpage&hl=en |newspaper=Idahonian |location=Moscow |last=Smith |first=Christopher |title=William Kibbie dies in car crash |date=February 12, 1988|page=1}}}} {{nowrap|The acronym "ASUI"}} is for the "Associated Students of the University of Idaho," the [[student government]]. When the university announced it would enclose its football stadium, the fledgling Trus-Joist Company of [[Boise, Idaho|Boise]] bid on and won the project. While [[steel]] and [[aluminum]] were the products of the day for domes and large unsupported buildings, Trus-Joist saw the UI stadium as a chance to demonstrate the strength, durability, and economy of their engineered wood products. From the final design to the end of construction, the enclosure project took just 10 months and $1 million to complete. In 1976, the Kibbie Dome roof won the "Structural Engineering Achievement Award" from the [[American Society of Civil Engineers]].[http://www.idahoptv.org/outdoors/shows/designingidaho/troutneressay.html idahoptv.org/outdoors/shows/designingidaho/troutneressay.html] TJ International, the successor to Trus-Joist, was acquired by [[Weyerhaeuser]] {{nowrap|in late 1999.[http://money.cnn.com/1999/11/23/deals/weyerhaeuser/index.htm money.cnn.com/1999/11/23/deals/weyerhaeuser/index.htm]}} ===Renovations=== Following the first indoor football season, the asphalt base underneath the field was covered with [[Tartan track|Tartan]] [[polyurethane]] in January 1976.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=860&dat=19751230&id=AYFUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WI8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=4518,5448650 |newspaper=Ellensburg Daily Record |location=Washington |title=Kibbie Dome work behind schedule |agency=UPI |date=December 30, 1975 |page=9}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1314&dat=19760111&id=3CBOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dO0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=7219,4176038 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |title=Kibbie Dome about to become track center, too |last=Payne |first=Bob |date=January 11, 1976 |page=D7}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9bBfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4jIMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3556,3353347 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=Idaho |title=Shaving it close in Kibbie Dome |last=Emerson |first=Paul |date=January 13, 1976 |page=1-sports}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=nPMjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=b-0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=7424,1221862 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |title=Idaho track, hoop soaring |last=Payne |first=Bob |date=January 18, 1976 |page=D5}} The first basketball game was played on January 21, and the inaugural Vandal Invitational indoor track meet was held three days later.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_7BfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4jIMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2596,5969474 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=Idaho |title=Kibbie track should be ready |date=January 23, 1976 |page=3B}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=AbFfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4jIMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5497%2C6560074 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=Idaho |title=Feuerbach, Cougars steal show in dome |last=Spotleson |first=Bruce |date=January 25, 1976|page=1B}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=pPMjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=b-0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6653,4074682 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |title=Initial Vandal Indoor called 'artistic' |last=Payne |first=Bob |date=January 26, 1976 |page=13}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=A7FfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4jIMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5027,7083688 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=Idaho |last=Spotleson |first=Bruce |title=Dome has every ingredient but track fans |date=January 27, 1976 |page=1B}} The Kibbie Dome's roof spans {{convert|400|ft|round=5}} from sideline-to-sideline, and its maximum height is {{convert|150|ft|round=5}} above the hashmarks. ([[Holt Arena]], completed in 1970 on the campus of [[Idaho State University]] in [[Pocatello, Idaho|Pocatello]], has an opposite geometry: its arched roof spans the ''length'' of the football field, rather than its width, resulting in a very low roof at the end lines and goal posts.) Soon after completion in 1975, problems arose with the roof's exterior. The {{convert|4.5|acre|ha|adj=on}} outer surface of [[Hypalon]] and underlying polyurethane foam were improperly applied and a second attempt to seal the roof with Diathon in the late 1970s did not succeed. Leaks were occurring and [[Wood-decay fungus|wood rot]] was a potential problem by 1980. An [[infrared]] scan of the roof in the spring of 1981 showed that half of it was moist and the insulating foam was in poor condition. Various stopgap measures were taken to stop the leaks in 1981.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zPZLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Zu4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5314,5569889 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |agency=photo |title=The sun shines through the roof... |date=July 14, 1981 |page=8}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=nYRfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_TAMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4930,1099448 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=Idaho |title=Dome roof: If at first you don't succeed...|date=November 3, 1981 |page=3B}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=n4RfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_TAMAAAAIBAJ&dq=roof%20kibbie&pg=6137%2C2039427 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=Idaho |agency=photo |title=Kibbie Dome roof repairs |date=November 5, 1981 |page=1C}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jZxfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=rDEMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2828,5569889 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=Idaho |title=Kibbie Dome's drip is conquered |last=Moulton |first=Kristen |date=December 12, 1981 |page=1C}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ALleAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vjAMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5546,3100257 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=Idaho |title=Contractors seek Kibbie Dome repair bid |date=June 23, 1982 |page=1B}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zbheAAAAIBAJ&sjid=oDAMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5850,1046805 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=Idaho |title=Lawyers ponder options in Kibbie Dome claims |agency=Associated Press |date=September 3, 1982 |page=6C}} After an extended period of finger-pointing and threatened legal action, an out-of-court settlement was reached. A new superstructure with a composite roof was built over the original.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=T11OAAAAIBAJ&sjid=afkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6876,25969|newspaper=Spokane Chronicle|location=Washington|title=Roof of Kibbie Dome receiving 'umbrella' |last=Ledford |first=David |date=September 1, 1982 |page=5}} Completed in the fall of [[1982 Idaho Vandals football team|1982]], coinciding with the completion of the East End Addition, the second roof shielded the first and solved the problem.{{cite web|url=http://issuu.com/uidahodigital/docs/gem1978/280 |publisher=''Gem of the Mountains'', University of Idaho yearbook |title=If it rains or it snows |year=1978 |page=276}}{{cite web|url=http://issuu.com/uidahodigital/docs/gem1982/72 |publisher=''Gem of the Mountains'', University of Idaho yearbook |title=Continuing controversies |year=1981 |page=68}}{{cite web|url=http://issuu.com/uidahodigital/docs/gem1983/86 |publisher=''Gem of the Mountains'', University of Idaho yearbook |title=The saga of the leaky dome |year=1983 |page=82}} ==Football== The Kibbie Dome officially seats just 16,000 for football, making it the second smallest venue in [[Football Bowl Subdivision|Division I FBS]] (formerly Division I-A). A record crowd of 19,878 was recorded for the eightth consecutive [[Boise State–Idaho rivalry|rivalry game]] victory over [[1989 Boise State Broncos football team|Boise State]] in November [[1989 Idaho Vandals football team|1989]], during the schools' I-AA [[Big Sky Conference|Big Sky]] era. The football field runs an unorthodox east-west, but even with the new translucent upper end walls ([[2009 Idaho Vandals football team|2009]] and [[2011 Idaho Vandals football team|2011]]), sun location is not a major visibility issue. For two and a half seasons, 1999 to 2001, the Vandals used [[Washington State University|WSU]]'s [[Martin Stadium]] in nearby [[Pullman, Washington|Pullman]] as its home field, as Idaho transitioned back to [[Football Bowl Subdivision|Division I-A]] from [[Football Championship Subdivision|Division I-AA]]. When [[Dennis Erickson]] returned as head coach in [[2006 Idaho Vandals football team|2006]], there was talk of adding a second deck to the Kibbie Dome to increase the football seating to 25,000, and building a new basketball arena. In February 2007, the state board of education appropriated funds to study expansion possibilities. On December 6, the board approved funding to begin design work for $52 million in improvements, including an expansion to 20,000 seats, lowering the elevation of the playing field, and other various safety and spectator improvements.[http://www.idahostatesman.com/vandalsports/story/231555.html idahostatesman.com/vandalsports/story/231555.html] When not used for football, the former [[AstroTurf]] football field was rolled up in about an hour to reveal {{convert|93000|sqft|acre ha|abbr=off}} of polyurethane tartan surface, used for indoor tennis and track & field. The five-lane track is {{convert|290|m|yd|abbr=off}} in length, and 9 tennis courts are lined on its infield. Basketball and volleyball courts are also lined on the tartan infield. The AstroTurf was spooled onto a large field-width reel at the base of the west wall. In 1990, the original synthetic turf (3M Tartan Turf) of [[1972 Idaho Vandals football team|1972]] was replaced after 18 seasons, which included three years outdoors.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1NctAAAAIBAJ&sjid=v9AFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5621%2C2707369 |newspaper=Idahonian |location=Moscow |last=Smith |first=Christopher |title=Roll out the carpet |date=June 10, 1989 |page=1A }} In the summer of 2007, the Kibbie Dome's AstroTurf was replaced with RealGrass Pro, a next-generation infilled synthethic turf similar to [[Field Turf]].[http://www.govandals.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=17100&ATCLID=1136611 govandals.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=17100&ATCLID=1136611] Unlike the carpet-like AstroTurf, the infilled synthetic turf is not easily rolled up in a continuous reel, and must be removed in sections. The turf sections are {{convert|5|yd|spell=in}} in width, running from sideline to sideline, attached to each other with [[velcro]]. Other stadiums with RealGrass Pro include [[Texas Stadium]] (the former home of the [[Dallas Cowboys]]), and the [[Alamodome]] in [[San Antonio, Texas|San Antonio]]. Life and safety upgrades to the Kibbie Dome began {{Time ago|2009|spellout=yes}} in the spring of [[2009 Idaho Vandals football team|2009]]. The west wall was replaced with a non-combustible construction assembly; [[translucent]] plastic panels on the upper half and [[Opacity (optics)|opaque]] metal siding on the lower. Concurrent with the end-wall replacement, a range of interior life safety work took place: field level exiting in the new west wall, addition of handrails in the seating aisles, provision of the required smoke exhaust systems; and other life safety and code mitigation improvements. The second phase of the project was completed in [[2011 Idaho Vandals football team|2011]] with the replacement of the east wall. A premium seating area (Litehouse Center) was established in 2011 in the former press box area above the south grandstand; a new press box was constructed above the north grandstand. ==Basketball== The stadium has also served as the home of the Vandal basketball teams, providing increased [[seating capacity]] over the venerable [[Memorial Gymnasium (University of Idaho)|Memorial Gym]] (built in 1928), a block to the east. The basketball court is positioned at midfield on the south sideline, in front of the press box and the south grandstand, with temporary seating on the north, east, and west. The first basketball game was played against [[Washington State Cougars men's basketball|WSU]] on {{Start date and age|1976|01|21}}, commemorated with a visit by Vandal great [[Gus Johnson (basketball)|Gus Johnson]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_bBfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4jIMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5873%2C5364449 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=Idaho |title=Dome opener |last=Emerson |first=Paul |date=January 21, 1976 |page=1B}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_LBfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4jIMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4290%2C5163165 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=Idaho |title=Idaho cage great Gus Johnson returns to Palouse |last=Barrows |first=Bob |date=January 20, 1976 |page=1B}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_rBfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4jIMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4183%2C5586383 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=Idaho |title=WSU also captures alumni game 74-63 |last=Spotleson |first=Bruce |date=January 22, 1976 |page=1B}} The main court was originally smooth tartan rubber, poured directly onto the pavement floor, resulting in a very hard and unforgiving surface, but resulted in a tremendous home court advantage under head coach [[Don Monson]] in the early 1980s. After nine seasons, it was replaced with a conventional hardwood floor in the fall of 1984, acquired from the [[Arizona Wildcats men's basketball|University of Arizona]] in [[Tucson, Arizona|Tucson]].{{cite news |url=https://digital.lib.uidaho.edu/cdm/ref/collection/argonaut/id/9790?_ga=2.132077324.2092029922.1539109752-2101260250.1525192126 |work=Argonaut |location=(Moscow, Idaho) |agency=(University of Idaho) |title=Dome to be home for hoop court |date=August 28, 1984 |page=28}} During basketball games, the converted Kibbie Dome is now referred to as the '''Cowan Spectrum''', named for '''Bob''' and '''Jan Cowan''', who financed the current configuration. Since February 2001, the new basketball layout has been separated from the rest of the stadium by massive black curtains to give the court a more intimate "stadium-within-a-stadium" feel, with a reduced [[seating capacity]] of 7,000. Temporary OES scoreboards are placed over the north and south stands during games. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UMrWjNbtbGc (video)] During the early 1980s, with [[Don Monson]] as head coach, the Kibbie Dome was considered one of the 20 toughest home courts in [[college basketball]] by ''[[Sports Illustrated]].'' Additional temporary seating was gradually increased on the north basketball sideline and attendance exceeded 11,000 for several games during the [[Don Monson#1982–83 season|1982–83]] season.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-rxeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CDEMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4182%2C1633153 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=Idaho |last=Killen |first=John |title=Vandals nip Cougars in OT, 62-58 |date=December 5, 1982 |page=1B}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=R5xfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ojEMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4823%2C3714993 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=Idaho |title=Snap! Montana breaks it all to stop Idaho |date=February 13, 1983 |page=1B}} From January 1980 to February 1983, the Vandals won 43 consecutive home games, and Monson's home record in his final four seasons was 51–2 ({{winning percentage|51|2}}). A Big Sky record attendance of 11,800 witnessed the streak end against [[Montana Grizzlies basketball|Montana]]. The venue hosted three [[Big Sky Conference]] men's basketball tournaments (by winning the regular season title), in 1981, 1982, and 1993. (The Vandals departed the [[Big Sky Conference|Big Sky]] for the [[Big West Conference|Big West]] in 1996, then to the [[Western Athletic Conference|WAC]] in 2005 before returning its non-football sports to the Big Sky in 2014.) ==Additions== [[File:2008-1018-019-KibbieDome-east.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The east side of the Kibbie Dome features the East End Addition (center), the Vandal Athletic Center (right), and SprinTurf practice fields. (2008)]] Since its enclosure in 1975, the Kibbie Dome has undergone several significant additions. The East End Addition was completed in the fall of [[1982 Idaho Vandals football team|1982]], providing the entire athletic department with locker rooms, offices, a weight room, athletic training facility, and equipment room. The formal dedication and open house for the $3.9 million addition was held in late October.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=db9eAAAAIBAJ&sjid=STEMAAAAIBAJ&pg=6090%2C1699361 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=Idaho |title=Open house planned at dome addition |date=October 20, 1982 |page=7C}} Until the addition, the football and basketball teams, both Vandals and visitors, dressed in the Memorial Gym and made the lengthy walk (or run) west to the Kibbie Dome, often in rain or snow. This had been the practice for UI football for over 40 years, since the opening of [[Neale Stadium]] in 1937. Bill Kibbie also made a significant donation for this project in 1979.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jtIvAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LPkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4206%2C164634 |newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle |location=Washington |title=Kibbie gift aids dome |date=December 1, 1979 |page=3 }} In April 2004, the facilities were again enhanced with the addition of the {{convert|8000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} Vandal Athletic Center, designed by [http://www.opsisarch.com Opsis Architecture], home to the Norm and Becky Iverson Speed and Strength Center; the renovation of the men's and women's basketball, football, and volleyball locker rooms, and the addition of a state-of-the-art hydrotherapy pool (ARC).[http://www.govandals.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=17100&KEY=&ATCLID=1257088 govandals.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=17100&KEY=&ATCLID=1257088] ==Adjacent practice fields== [[File:UI-kibbee-moscow-id-us.png|300px|thumb|Kibbie Dome from the far west in [[2007 Idaho Vandals football team|2007]]]] August 2005 saw the installation of infilled SprinTurf on the former natural grass practice field east of the Kibbie Dome. The days of "off-limits" were eliminated, as UI students acquired state-of-the-art playing fields available for year-round use. A field that previously had just 300 usable hours annually as an "intercollegiate athletics only" field (primarily for natural turf varsity football practice), is now available for up to 2,000 hours per year. The project was funded through the Kibbie Dome turf replacement fund; the $1.2 million SprinTurf project included lighting and fencing. The two {{convert|75|yd|adj=on}} fields are adequate for team practice for football (and soccer, lacrosse, rugby, and other sports) as well as for intramural competition, but short enough to have two fields in the space available. Each field is a full half-field (with end zone & goal post) plus an additional {{convert|15|yd}} beyond the 50-yard line. An unmarked {{convert|10|yd|0|adj=on}} median separates the two fields; the total length, with end zones, is {{convert|160|yd|0}} and runs north-south. The former natural turf fields were lined as a regulation football field running north-south, with a half field at the north end running east-west. An added benefit of the synthetic surface is an estimated $50,000 annual savings in field maintenance costs. [http://idaho.scout.com/2/380503.html idaho.scout.com/2/380503.html] ==Nearby facilities== On the west side of the Kibbie Dome is the [[Dan O'Brien]] outdoor track & field stadium, which hosted its first meet in 1972,{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=gbBfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5DIMAAAAIBAJ&pg=6176,5667800 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=Idaho |title=Collie Mack leads Idaho cinder win on new track |date=April 23, 1972 |page=13}} and was renamed in [[1996 Summer Olympics|1996]] for the [[Athletics at the 1996 Summer Olympics – Men's decathlon|Olympic gold medalist]] world champion and former world record holder in the [[decathlon]]. A concrete grandstand at the finish area (southeast corner) has a seating capacity of 1,000. The first all-weather surface lasted less than a decade and was replaced in 1980.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QMBeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=VTEMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3541,9323454 |newspaper= Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=Idaho |title=UI to get new track |date=August 26, 1979 |page=4C}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ZgYkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=XO4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=2725,1629571 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |title=Vandals go outside to open new track |date=April 4, 1981 |page=18}} The facility underwent a major renovation in 2011 to host the 2012 WAC outdoor championships.[http://www.uidaho.edu/facilities/projectinfo/track University of Idaho] – Facilities Services – Dan O'Brien Track Complex Renovation – accessed 2011-11-20 South of the Dome is the [[University of Idaho Golf Course|university's 18-hole golf course]], a challenging track due to its rolling [[Palouse]] terrain. A par-72 course with terraced fairways and significant changes in elevation, its back tees measure {{convert|6637|yd|m}}, with a course rating of 72.4, and a 135 slope rating.[http://www.usga.org/playing/handicaps/course_ratings/course_rating_results.asp?coid=UNIVERSITY+OF+IDAHO+GC&coname=UNIVERSITY+OF+IDAHO+GC&cocity=MOSCOW&costate=ID&MW=M USGA.org] – Univ. of Idaho Golf Course The course opened in 1937 with nine holes, then expanded from 1968–70, with the present clubhouse opening in 1969.[http://www.auxserv.uidaho.edu/golf auxserv.uidaho.edu/golf] To the east is the [[Memorial Gymnasium (University of Idaho)|Memorial Gymnasium]] (1928), the [[human swimming|swim]] center and the [[physical education]] building (both 1970), and six outdoor [[tennis]] courts. Four additional tennis courts are on the east side of campus, at the southeast corner of the Administration Lawn. About a half mile north (800 m) of the Dome are expansive natural grass intramural fields, west of the Wallace dormitories. Included here is the women's [[soccer]] field, in the far northwest corner bounded by Perimeter Road. Towards the center is [https://admin.xosn.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=17100&ATCLID=1583679 Guy Wicks] Field, the baseball field since the late 1960s. ([[Idaho Vandals baseball|Baseball]] was dropped as a varsity sport after the 1980 season,{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=CFZOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Re4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5702,6845869 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |title=Baseball's 'out' at Idaho |last=Goodwin |first=Dale |date=May 13, 1980|page=19}} after more than 80 seasons, but continues as a club sport.) ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I FBS football stadiums]] * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{Infobox cricket ground | ground_name = Old Hararians Sports Club | nickname = | image = | caption = | country = Zimbabwe | location = [[Harare]], [[Zimbabwe]] | coordinates = {{coord|17|48|53.49|S|31|01|38.49|E|type:landmark|display=it}} | establishment = | seating_capacity = | owner = [[Zimbabwe Cricket]] | operator = Zimbabwe Cricket | architect = | tenants = [[Zimbabwe national cricket team|Zimbabwe]]
[[Mashonaland cricket team]]
[[Rising Stars cricket team|Rising Stars]] | end1 = | end2 = | international = true | firsttestdate = | firsttestyear = | firsttesthome = | firsttestaway = | lasttestdate = | lasttestyear = | lasttesthome = | lasttestaway = | firstodidate = 6 March | firstodiyear = 2018 | firstodihome = United Arab Emirates | firstodiaway = West Indies | lastodidate = 20 March | lastodiyear = 2018 | lastodihome = Afghanistan | lastodiaway = United Arab Emirates | firstt20idate = | firstt20iyear = | firstt20ihome = | firstt20iaway = | lastt20idate = | lastt20iyear = | lastt20ihome = | lastt20iaway = | year1 = | club1 = | year2 = | club2 = | year3 = | club3 = | date = 8 March | year = 2018 | source = http://www.espncricinfo.com/zimbabwe/content/ground/59547.html ESPNcricinfo }} '''Old Hararians Sports Club''' is a sports club and [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Harare]], [[Zimbabwe]].{{cite web|url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/news/629552 |title=Old Hararians Sports Club |publisher=International Cricket Council |accessdate=2 March 2018}} The ground is also known as Old Hararians 'B' Field, it is mostly used for [[cricket]] matches, and has served as the cricket venue in Zimbabwe since its foundation. ==The venue== The ground played host to an ICC Emerging Nations Tournament conducted by the [[International Cricket Council]] in 2000 and played host to five matches.{{cite web|url=http://static.espncricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/1999-2000/OTHERS+ICC/ICCENT/ICCENT_APRIL2000_SCHEDULE.html |title=ICC Emerging Nations Tournament Schedule |publisher=ESPN Cricinfo |accessdate=23 February 2018}} The ground underwent renovation ahead of the [[2018 Cricket World Cup Qualifier]]. The revamps were done to make the ground suitable for hosting international matches.{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/zimbabwe/content/story/1128918.html|title=ZC postpones domestic cricket amid cash shortage |publisher=ESPN Cricinfo |accessdate=23 February 2018}} At the 2018 Cricket World Cup Qualifier, during the playoff matches, [[Nepal national cricket team|Nepal]] gained [[One Day International]] (ODI) status following their match at the ground.{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/story/_/id/22777050/biggest-day-nepal-cricket-history-khadka|title='Biggest day in Nepal cricket history' - Khadka |publisher=ESPN Cricinfo |accessdate=15 March 2018}} On 17 March 2018, the ninth place playoff match between [[Papua New Guinea national cricket team|Papua New Guinea]] and [[Hong Kong national cricket team|Hong Kong]] at the Cricket World Cup Qualifier became the 4,000th ODI match to be played.{{Cite web |url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/news/645751 |title=PNG defend 200 to take ninth place |accessdate=17 March 2018 |work=International Cricket Council}} ==International centuries== ===One Day International centuries=== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:95%" ! No. !! Score !! Player !! Team !! Balls !! Opposing team !! Date !! Result |- | 1 || 123 || [[Chris Gayle]] || {{cr|WIN}} || {{ntsh|910}} 91 || {{cr|UAE}} || {{dts|format=dmy|2018|March|6}} || Won |- | 2 || 127 || [[Shimron Hetmyer]] || {{cr|WIN}} || {{ntsh|930}} 93 || {{cr|UAE}} || {{dts|format=dmy|2018|March|6}} || Won |- | 3 || 112* || [[Rameez Shahzad]] || {{cr|UAE}} || {{ntsh|1070}} 107 || {{cr|WIN}} || {{dts|format=dmy|2018|March|6}} || Lost |- | 4 || 126 || [[Paul Stirling]] || {{cr|IRE}} || {{ntsh|1170}} 117 || {{cr|UAE}} || {{dts|format=dmy|2018|March|12}} ||Won |} ==See also== * [[List of cricket grounds by capacity]] * [[List of One Day International cricket grounds]] * [[List of international cricket five-wicket hauls in Zimbabwe cricket grounds#Old Hararians|List of international cricket five-wicket hauls in Zimbabwe cricket grounds § Old Hararians]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://content.cricinfo.com/zimbabwe/content/ground/59547.html Profile] by [[Cricinfo]] {{Cricket in Zimbabwe}} [[Category:Cricket grounds in Zimbabwe]] [[Category:Sport in Harare]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Harare]]

{{Infobox Comic strip |title= Out of Bounds |image= |creator= Don Wilder | illustrator = [[Bill Rechin]] |status= Concluded, in reruns |syndicate= [[News America Syndicate]] (1986–1987)
[[News America Syndicate]] (1987–1997)
Crock Associates (self-syndication) (1997–1998)Holtz, Allan. [https://strippersguide.blogspot.com/2013/01/obscurity-of-day-out-of-bounds.html "Obscurity of the Day: Out of Bounds,"] ''Stripper's Guide'' (Jan. 9, 2013). | genre= Humor, Sports |first= {{start date and age|1986}} |last= {{end date and age|1998}} |website= }} '''Out of Bounds''' is a comic strip by [[Don Wilder]] (1934–2008) and [[Bill Rechin]] (1930–2011). It was first syndicated in 1986. Rechin received the [[National Cartoonist Society]] Newspaper Panel Cartoon Award for 1992 for his work on the strip. ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite web |publisher=National Cartoonists Society |title=Awards: Newspaper Panel |url=http://www.reuben.org/divisions.html#panel |accessdate=September 14, 2010}} {{cite book |last=Strickler |first=Dave |title=Syndicated Comic Strips and Artists, 1924-1995: The Complete Index |location=Cambria, CA |publisher=Comics Access |year=1995 |isbn=0-9700077-0-1}} }} ==External links== *[http://www.reuben.org/ncs/awards.asp NCS Awards] [[Category:American comic strips]] [[Category:1986 comics debuts]] [[Category:Gag-a-day comics]] [[Category:Sports comics]] {{comic-strip-stub}}

{{inline|date=October 2014}} [[Image:RPWlogo.jpg|thumb|right|150px|'''Real Pro Wrestling''''s Logo.]] '''Real Pro Wrestling''' (also known as '''RPW''' or '''RealPro Wrestling''') was a [[professional]] [[sports league]] of [[wrestling]], similar to the [[amateur wrestling]] found in the [[Olympic Games]] and at the [[collegiate wrestling|college]] and [[scholastic wrestling|high school]] level. The term "real" was meant to emphasize that it was [[professional]] (meaning the wrestlers are paid money) and it was wrestling, but that it was not [[professional wrestling]] in the traditional sense; modern professional wrestling features [[work (professional wrestling)|predetermined outcomes]] and operates under a very different [[Professional wrestling#Rules|set of rules]] from amateur wrestling.
Real Pro Wrestling, Inc was founded in 2002 by former [[Northwestern University]] wrestling teammates Toby Willis and Matt Case. The company was based in [[Nashville, Tennessee]] with branch offices in New York and Virginia. RPW was a television production company and a producer of live events.
The league began operations in March 2005 and consisted of eight teams (see below). Although the teams had various city and state names, all matches were taped on a soundstage in Nashville and Los Angeles (Los Angeles Center Studios).
According to [https://web.archive.org/web/20050126155145/http://realprowrestling.com/ the official website], "In RPW, classic meets the future as the matches are conducted in a specially designed coliseum which showcases a raised circular mat to facilitate better camera angles and to afford the live audience a better viewing experience. The circular mat allows for 360 degree camera angles and aids in covering the close quarters that wrestlers frequently find themselves in as they maneuver for position."
Numerous similar projects were announced before RPW, but none had gotten off the ground. Lanny Bryant, the [[Montana]]-based editor of ''Wrestling USA'' magazine, proposed a similar league in the early 1990s, as one example.
RPW folded in 2007, after two seasons (2004 and 2006-7).
In the spring of 2013, the Association of Career Wrestlers formed a new series offering competitions with financial incentives for post-collegiate wrestlers called [http://touracw.com Tour ACW]. This new series has a new set of rules building on the RPW rules with an emphasis on scoring.<ref>http://www.intermatwrestle.com/articles/11869</ref>
==Wrestling style== The style of wrestling that is used in ''RPW'' is a combination of [[Freestyle wrestling|freestyle]], [[folkstyle|American Folkstyle]], [[Sumo|sumo wrestling]] and [[Greco-Roman wrestling]]. Because of this, wrestlers of many styles competed in the league. Greco-Roman and Freestyle were the most common wrestling backgrounds in the leagues, due largely to the Olympic experience of the wrestlers in the league. In fact, the team rosters consists of numerous Olympians and [[NCAA]] champions.
==Rules== The rules were similar to [[Freestyle wrestling#Scoring|freestyle wrestling]] but were modified to encourage risk and intensity. The goal is to dominate the opponent and pin his shoulders to the mat. This is called a fall. Points are also awarded during the six-minute match for controlling the opponent, placing him in danger, or escaping the opponent's control. If there is no fall, then the wrestler with the most points wins the match. Some of the most noticeable changes were as follows: # Two 3-minute periods instead of 3 periods totaling 7 minutes # If a wrestler pushed his opponent out of the ring he would get a point. # '''The Bonus''' - if a wrestler manages to stay in the center of the mat and stay aggressive, their ''bonus meter'' would go up. If they got the bonus, they would get to go into a special position in which they couldn't lose any points and could gain points by throwing their opponents. # '''TV Challenge''' - the coach of each wrestler is allowed once per individual match to challenge a call made by the ''Ref'' using video from multiple video angles.
==Teams== *California Claw *Chicago Groove *Iowa Stalkers *Minnesota Freeze *New York Outrage *Oklahoma Slam *Pennsylvania Hammer *Texas Shooters
==League structure== Despite the existence of eight "franchises" in RPW, all tournaments were conducted in a classic elimination bracket format. No actual [[dual meet]]s were held.
==Television coverage== In the league's first season, 2005–06, matches were televised on PAX TV (now [[ION Television]]) on Sunday evenings and on [[Fox Sports Net]] affiliates at various times. [[Rulon Gardner]], one of the most famous figures in amateur wrestling in the [[United States]], was the [[color analyst]]. Veteran Radio and Television Sports Announcer Chip Hoback from Nashville, TN did the Voice Over and Highlights.
Due to executive reorganizations at both networks, both PAX and FSN pulled the show. RPW then decided to syndicate coverage of the second season on various [[terrestrial television|broadcast stations]].
In an [http://thewrestlingmall.com/stories/rpw_willis_interview.php interview] with [http://www.thewrestlingmall.com/ The Wrestling Mall] co-founder Toby Willis also revealed that although sponsors and investors were already lined up for Season 2 a few employees had attempted a "take over" of the company which also added to the downfall of the league. In the same series of articles Mr. Willis stated his wish that wrestling would adopt more of a martial arts mentality to draw in more kids. Mr. Willis said, "Wrestling desperately needs to rebrand itself as a martial art not just another arbitrary sport. We need to use military terminology and martial art vocabulary. We need to teach it as self defense. So instead of the high school coach walking up to a kid in the hallways of school and asking them to try wrestling, they should ask the kid if he wants to learn self defense. What kid says they want to be defenseless? Then when the kid shows up for practice, the coach has to teach wrestling from a martial arts perspective."
==Notable participants==
*[[Muhammed Lawal]] - Season 1 Champion, NCAA Division II champion and Freestyle World Championships competitor (7th place), current mixed martial artist with [[Bellator MMA|Bellator]], and former [[List of Strikeforce champions#Light Heavyweight Championship|Strikeforce Light Heavyweight Champion]]. *[[Andy Hrovat]] - wrestled at [[2008 Olympics]] and defeated Muhammed Lawal at the 2008 U.S. Olympic Trials. *[[Daniel Cormier]] - Season 1 Champion, two-time Olympic Freestyle Wrestler and 2008 U.S. team captain, King of the Cage Champion, Strikeforce Heavyweight Grand Prix Champion and the current [[Ultimate Fighting Championship|UFC]] light heavyweight, and heavyweight champion. *[[Teague Moore]] - U.S. Open Champion, College Wrestling Coach, & Founder of the Association of Career Wrestlers. *[[Aaron Simpson (fighter)|Aaron Simpson]] - 11 [[Ultimate Fighting Championship|UFC]] veteran, competing in both the Middle Weight and Welterweight division. Also a former competitor on [[American Gladiators]]. *[[Joe Warren (fighter)|Joe Warren]] - 2006 Greco-Roman World Championships gold medalist, current mixed martial artist with [[Bellator Fighting Championships]], and [[List_of_Bellator_champions#Bellator Tournaments|Bellator Season 2 Featherweight Tournament]] winner and former [[List_of_Bellator_champions#Featherweight Championship|Bellator Featherweight Champion]]. *[[Patrick Cummins (fighter)|Patrick Cummins]] (born November 16, 1980) is an American mixed martial artist.[5] He currently competes in the Light Heavyweight division of the Ultimate Fighting Championship. As of August 3, 2015, Cummins is #12 in official UFC Light Heavyweight rankings. [6]
==Champions== *Season 1: {| class="wikitable" width="50%" style="text-align:center;" !style="background:#e3e3e3;" width="10%"|Weight Division !style="background:#e3e3e3;" width="25%"|Champion !style="background:#e3e3e3;" width="10%"|Team |- |{{convert|121|lb|kg |abbr=on}} ||align=left|{{flagicon|USA}} [[Sammie Henson]] || align=center| Pennsylvania Hammer |- |{{convert|132|lb|kg |abbr=on}} ||align=left|{{flagicon|USA}} Tony DeAnda || align=center| New York Outrage |- |{{convert|145|lb|kg |abbr=on}} ||align=left|{{flagicon|USA}} [[Doug Schwab]] || align=center| Iowa Stalkers |- |{{convert|163|lb|kg |abbr=on}} ||align=left|{{flagicon|USA}} [[Joe Williams (wrestler)|Joe Williams]] || align=center| Chicago Groove |- |{{convert|184|lb|kg |abbr=on}} ||align=left|{{flagicon|USA}} [[Muhammed Lawal]] || align=center| Oklahoma Slam |- |{{convert|211|lb|kg |abbr=on}} ||align=left|{{flagicon|USA}} [[Daniel Cormier]] || align=center| Oklahoma Slam |- |{{convert|264|lb|kg |abbr=on}} ||align=left|{{flagicon|USA}} [[Patrick Cummins (fighter)|Patrick Cummins]] || align=center| Pennsylvania Hammer |- |}

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Use British English|date=March 2016}} '''Rimmington (Kent cricketer)''' refers to three brothers who played [[first-class cricket]] for [[Essex county cricket teams|Essex]], [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] and [[All-England Eleven|All-England]] teams between the [[1777 English cricket season|1777 and 1791 seasons]].
Personal details of them are unknown apart from their initials which were B, T and M. Their known appearances were 6, 5 and 1 respectively. But, as often happened at the time with other brothers and namesakes, when just one of them played only the surname was recorded and there are another 15 matches in which an unidentified Rimmington took part.
In 1780, B Rimmington was one of the most successful batsmen of the season, scoring 130 runs in only 3 matches.
It is believed the Rimmingtons were from Kent and they were originally involved with Kent cricket, but references to them from 1785 indicate that they joined the prominent Hornchurch Club and played for Essex.
== References == * ''Fresh Light on 18th Century Cricket'' by [[G B Buckley]] (FL18) * ''Scores & Biographies, Volume 1'' by [[Arthur Haygarth]] (SBnnn) * ''The Dawn of Cricket'' by [[H T Waghorn]] (WDC)
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rimmington}} [[Category:English cricketers]] [[Category:Essex cricketers]] [[Category:Kent cricketers]] [[Category:English cricketers of 1701 to 1786]] [[Category:White Conduit Club cricketers]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/185.32.178.36|185.32.178.36]] ([[User talk:185.32.178.36|talk]]) to last revision by Chrism. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=February 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} '''Rule 42''' (now '''Rule 5.1'''<ref name="2009 official guide">{{cite web|url=http://www.gaa.ie/files/official_guides/2009_official_guide_part1.pdf |title=2009 official guide part1 |accessdate=2010-01-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110220183429/http://www.gaa.ie/files/official_guides/2009_official_guide_part1.pdf |archivedate=20 February 2011 |df= }}</ref> and '''Rule 44'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gaa.ie/files/official_guides/official_guide1_june10.pdf |title=2008 official guide part1 |accessdate=2010-01-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090915031813/http://www.gaa.ie/files/official_guides/official_guide1_june10.pdf |archivedate=15 September 2009 |df= }}</ref> in the 2008 guide) is a rule of the [[Gaelic Athletic Association]] (GAA) which in practice prohibits the playing of non-[[Gaelic games]] in GAA stadiums. The rule is often mistakenly believed to prohibit ''[[Glossary of Gaelic games terms#F|foreign sports]]'' at GAA owned [[List of GAA stadiums|stadiums]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/why-gaa-needs-this-dose-of-reality-1218743.html|title= Why GAA needs this dose of reality|accessdate=2010-01-07 | work=Irish Independent|first=Eugene|last=McGee|date=14 November 2007}}</ref> However, non-Gaelic games such as [[boxing]] and [[American football]] did [[List of non-Gaelic games played in Croke Park|take place]] in [[Croke Park]] before Rule 42 was modified.
==The drive to have Rule 42 changed== In the early 2000s the GAA came under pressure to allow non-Gaelic games be played in Croke Park so that the [[Football Association of Ireland]] could be joint hosts of [[Euro 2008]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/northern_ireland/2259736.stm|title=Croke Park ruled out for Euro 2008|accessdate=2010-01-07 | work=BBC News | date=15 September 2002}}</ref> Subsequently the association was asked to modify the rule so that the [[Ireland national rugby union team]] and [[Republic of Ireland national football team]] would not have to play their home games outside Ireland while the [[Lansdowne Road]] stadium was being redeveloped.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/rugby_union/irish/3417359.stm|title=Green light for Lansdowne|accessdate=2010-01-07 | work=BBC News | date=27 January 2004}}</ref> A number of motions to change Rule 42 failed or were blocked from being put on the agenda<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archives.tcm.ie/roscommonherald/2004/11/04/story180.asp |title=Rule 42 debate will go ahead |accessdate=2010-01-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629113628/http://archives.tcm.ie/roscommonherald/2004/11/04/story180.asp |archivedate=29 June 2011 |df= }}</ref> with the majority of the opposition coming from the [[Ulster GAA|Ulster]] [[GAA county|counties]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4451933.stm |title=Gaelic angst over stadium decision |accessdate=2010-01-07 | work=BBC News | date=16 April 2005 | first=James | last=Helm}}</ref> The Rule was finally modified in 2005 to allow the playing of soccer and [[rugby union]] in [[Croke Park]] only while [[Lansdowne Road]] was being redeveloped. The motion gave the GAA's [[Structure of the Gaelic Athletic Association|central council]] the power to decide which games would be allowed in Croke Park.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2005/0416/gaa.html|title=GAA Congress Rule 42 decision welcomed|accessdate=2010-01-07 | work=RTÉ News|date=16 April 2005}}</ref> The motion to the GAA's [[Gaelic Athletic Association Congress|annual congress]] passed 227–97, thus obtaining the two-thirds majority required.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gaa.ie/plugins/newsfeed.cgi?rm=content&plugin_data_id=6101 |title=Rule 42 motion is carried |accessdate=2010-01-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306031401/http://www.gaa.ie/plugins/newsfeed.cgi?rm=content&plugin_data_id=6101 |archivedate= 6 March 2012 |df= }}</ref> ==When the redevelopment of Lansdowne Road is complete== It was agreed that once the redevelopment of Lansdowne Road (now called the [[Aviva Stadium]]) is complete Rule 42 will revert to its 2005 wording.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.planetrugby.com/Story/0,18259,3551_1902765,00.html |title=Ireland must wait to enjoy Croke craic |accessdate=2007-02-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927203757/http://www.planetrugby.com/Story/0%2C18259%2C3551_1902765%2C00.html |archivedate=27 September 2007 |df= }}</ref><ref name="2009 official guide"/> However, high profile GAA members including [[Seán Kelly (Irish politician)|Seán Kelly]], former [[List of Presidents of the Gaelic Athletic Association|GAA president]], have expressed the view that the rule should not be reversed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/2009/1015/walshn.html|title=Walsh wants Croker to stay open|accessdate=2010-01-07 | work=RTÉ News|date=15 October 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2009/1130/1224259709936.html|title=No sense in Croke Park reverting to ban, says Kelly|accessdate=2010-01-07 | work=The Irish Times|date=11 November 2009}}</ref> On 17 April 2010 the GAA voted to keep Croke Park open after the redevelopment of Lansdowne Road.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sports/gaa/2010/0417/1224268580815.html|title=Croke Park doors to remain open|accessdate=2010-04-18 | work=The Irish Times}}</ref>
==Outside Croke Park== In addition to the opening of Croke Park to competing sports, local GAA units have sought to rent their facilities out to other sports organisations for financial reasons in violation of Rule 42.<ref name="stateOfTheGame">{{cite news | url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/state-of-the-game-2566875.html | title=State of the Game | author=Martin Breheny | date=5 March 2011
| publisher=Irish Independent }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/facilities-for-gaa-use-only-cooney-2454052.html | title=Facilities for GAA use only: Cooney | date=9 December 2010 | accessdate=2011-03-09 | author=Donnchadh Boyle | publisher=Irish Independent }}</ref> The continued existence of Rule 42 has proven to be controversial since the management of Croke Park has been allowed to earn revenue by renting the facility out to competing sports organisations, but local GAA units which own smaller facilities cannot.<ref name="stateOfTheGame"/><ref name="colmORourkeRule42">{{cite news | url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/columnists/colm-orourke/colm-orourke-there-is-no-more-room-for-vanity-projects-in-the-gaa-2577493.html | title=There is no more room for vanity projects in the GAA | accessdate=14 March 2011 | author=O'Rourke, Colm | date=13 March 2011 | publisher=Sunday Independent}}</ref> It is also said that it is questionable as to whether or not such rental deals would actually be damaging to the GAA's interests.<ref name="stateOfTheGame"/>
==Wording of the rule== The original wording of Rule 42 is: {{Quote|Grounds controlled by Association units shall not be used or permitted to be used, for horse racing, greyhound racing, or for field games other than those sanctioned by Central Council.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gaelicfootball.eusu.ed.ac.uk/documents/GAA%20Official%20Guide%202003.pdf |title=2003 GAA Guide showing pre-2005 wording of Rule 42 |accessdate=2010-01-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110816230315/http://gaelicfootball.eusu.ed.ac.uk/documents/GAA%20Official%20Guide%202003.pdf |archivedate=16 August 2011 |df= }}</ref>}} The 2005 amendment added the sentence: {{quote|Central Council shall have the power to authorise the use of Croke Park for games, other than those controlled by the Association, during a temporary period when Lansdowne Road Football Ground is closed for the proposed development.<ref name="2009 official guide"/>}}
==The first games in Croke Park== The first game to take place under the relaxed Rule 42 took place on 11 February 2007. It was a [[Six Nations Championship]] rugby union match between [[Ireland national rugby union team|Ireland]] and [[France national rugby union team|France]] which Ireland lost 17–20.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/rugby_union/6352033.stm|title=Ireland 17–20 France|accessdate=2010-01-12 | work=BBC News | date=11 February 2007}}</ref> The following match against [[England national rugby union team|England]] generated some controversy, since it involved the playing of "[[God Save the Queen]]" at a ground where British soldiers had killed fourteen spectators on [[Bloody Sunday (1920)|Bloody Sunday, 1920]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mg.co.za/article/2007-02-09-foreign-rugby-invading-irelands-hallowed-ground|title='Foreign' rugby invading Ireland's hallowed ground|accessdate=2010-01-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/god-save-the-queen-at-joness-road-a-remarkable-moment-122168.html|title='God Save the Queen' at Jones's Road a remarkable moment'|accessdate=2010-01-12 | work=Irish Independent|first=John A|last=Murphy|date=18 February 2007}}</ref> There was a small protest by [[Republican Sinn Féin]] outside the ground. Ireland won the match by 43 points to 13.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/rugby/rugby-union/ireland-43-england-13-ireland-have-the-last-laugh-as-ashton-rues-massive-blip-437967.html|title= Ireland 43 England 13: Ireland have the last laugh as Ashton rues 'massive blip'|accessdate=2010-01-12 | work=The Independent | location=London | first=Chris | last=Hewett | date=26 February 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://conor.net/clog/wp-content/uploads/2007/02/srfron250207.jpg|title=Image showing man wearing Celtic tracksuit and holding sign|accessdate=2010-02-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indymedia.ie/article/81201|title=Republicans protest against "God Save The Queen" at Croker|accessdate=2010-01-12}}</ref>
==A world record attendance== In early February 2009, with possibility of an all Irish semi-final in the [[2008-09 Heineken Cup]], the GAA confirmed that club rugby would also be allowed under the relaxing of Rule 42.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ercrugby.com/eng/5019_12325.php |title=Croke Park lined up as potential semi-final venue |accessdate=2010-01-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20090218160942/http://www.ercrugby.com/eng/5019_12325.php |archivedate=18 February 2009 }}</ref> The [[2008-09 Heineken_Cup#Semi-finals|game]] was played in Croke Park on 2 May 2009, when [[Leinster Rugby|Leinster]] defeated [[Munster Rugby|Munster]] 25–6. The attendance of 82,208 set a new world record attendance for a club rugby union game.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_union/8030912.stm |title=Leinster 25–6 Munster||accessdate=2010-01-07 | work=BBC News | date=2 May 2009}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Rule 21]] * [[List of non-Gaelic games played in Croke Park]] * [[List of Gaelic Athletic Association stadiums]] * [[Sport in Ireland]]
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox national football team | Name = Russia Under-20 | Flag = Flag of Russia.svg | Badge = Coat_of_Arms_of_the_Russian_Federation_2.svg | FIFA Trigramme = RUS | Nickname = | Association = [[Russian Football Union]] | Confederation = [[UEFA]] (Europe) | Coach = [[Mikhail Galaktionov]] | Home Stadium = |pattern_la1=_russia1819h |pattern_b1=_russia1819h |pattern_ra1=_russia1819h |pattern_sh1=_rusl18h |pattern_so1=_rusl18h |leftarm1=FFFFFF |body1=FFFFFF |rightarm1=FFFFFF |shorts1=FFFFFF |socks1=FF0000 |pattern_la2=_rus18a |pattern_b2=_rus18a |pattern_ra2=_rus18a |pattern_sh2=_rus18a |pattern_so2=_3_stripes_white |socks2=E40303 | First game = | Largest win = | Largest loss = | Most Recent match = | U20WC apps = 8 {{small|''(6 as Soviet Union)''}} | U20WC first = | U20WC best = }}
The '''Russian national under-20 football team,''' formerly known as the '''Soviet national lads football team''' was the under-20 (for [[FIFA U-20 World Cup]]) and under-19 (for [[UEFA European Under-19 Championship|UEFA Under-19 Championship]]) [[football (soccer)|football]] teams of the [[Soviet Union]]. It ceased to exist on the [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)|breakup of the Union]], and was succeeded by the Russian national under-20 football team
Following the realignment of [[FIFA]]'s youth competitions in 1977, the [[Soviet Union national under-20 football team]] was formed and competed until 1993 (in 1992 it qualified as CIS youth under-18 football team) qualifying 7 times. Following [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]], the Soviet qualification was passed to Russia which competed in the [[1993 FIFA World Youth Championship]]. Two years later Russia managed to qualify for the tournament on its own effort, but since then it yet to qualify for it.
== FIFA U-20 World Cup Record == {{also|Soviet Union national under-20 football team}} * '''1993:''' Losing quarter-finalists. * '''1995:''' Losing quarter-finalists. * '''1997:''' Did not qualify. * '''1999:''' Did not qualify. * '''2001:''' Did not qualify. * '''2003:''' Did not qualify. * '''2005:''' Did not qualify. * '''2007:''' Did not qualify. * '''2011:''' Did not qualify. * '''2013:''' Did not qualify. * '''2015:''' Did not qualify. * '''2017:''' Did not qualify. * '''2019:''' Did not qualify.
