{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox UK place| |country = England |coordinates = {{coord|51.33242|0.17329|display=inline,title}} |official_name= Shoreham | civil_parish = Shoreham |population = 2,041 |population_ref = (2011 Census)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/LeadKeyFigures.do?a=7&b=11128466&c=Shoreham&d=16&e=62&g=6437896&i=1001x1003x1032x1004&m=0&r=1&s=1474292772238&enc=1|title=Civil Parish 2011|accessdate=19 September 2016|publisher=Office for National Statistics |work=Neighbourhood Statistics}}</ref> |shire_district= [[Sevenoaks (district)|Sevenoaks]] |shire_county = [[Kent]] |region= South East England |constituency_westminster= |post_town= Sevenoaks |postcode_district = TN14 |postcode_area= TN |dial_code= 01959 |os_grid_reference= TQ515615 }} [[Image:Shoreham bridge.jpg|thumb|Shoreham bridge over the Darent]]
'''Shoreham''' is a village and [[civil parishes in England|civil parish]] in the [[Sevenoaks District]] of [[Kent]], England. The parish includes the settlements of [[Badgers Mount]] and [[Well Hill]], and is located 5 miles north of [[Sevenoaks]].
The probable derivation of the name is ''estate at the foot of a steep slope''. Steep slope was from the Saxon word ''scor''. pronounced ''shor'', but written ''sore'' by Norman scribes.
The village of Shoreham contains four traditional independent pubs: Ye Olde George Inne, The King's Arms, The Two Brewers and the Crown; with another in nearby Twitton.
==History== The Darent valley was one of the major areas of [[Stone Age]] settlement; Shoreham is not mentioned in the [[Domesday Book]].
In 1668, [[cricket]] was mentioned in a court case as being played at Shoreham, one of the sport's earliest references.<ref>Underdown, pp. 12–13.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/main.html |title=From Lads to Lord's; The History of Cricket: 1300 – 1787 |publisher=Stumpsite |first=John |last=Leach |date=2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629134518/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/main.html |archivedate=29 June 2011}}</ref>
It was also known as a [[smuggling]] area. Moreover, Shoreham was the most bombed village in the United Kingdom during the Second World War because the Army took over several manor houses for operational use.{{Citation needed|date=September 2013}}
Papermaking was once a local industry; the mill closed finally in 1925.
==War memorial== There is a white memorial cross in the hillside opposite the village church. It was dug in 1920 as a memorial to local men killed in action.
Shoreham was the birthplace and home of Private [[Thomas Highgate]], who was the first British soldier to be shot for [[desertion]] during the [[First World War]] on 8 September 1914, following the [[Battle of Mons|Battle of]] and [[Great Retreat|Retreat from Mons]]. In 2000, Shoreham Parish Council voted not to include his name on its war memorial. However, after a posthumous pardon in 2006, it was considered that his name might be added.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/4798025.stm |title=England | Shot at dawn, pardoned 90 years on |publisher=BBC News |date=16 August 2006 |accessdate=2014-03-02}}</ref>
The memorial is incomplete. It has been established that at least one of its fallen, George Arthur Rouse (brother of Percy Aslin, marked on the memorial, both sons of Harriet Rouse, as recorded in the 1901 Census), is missing. One hundred years after he died, an effort to have George added was underway.{{cn|date=August 2018}}
==Shoreham Aircraft Museum== The official opening of the [[Shoreham Aircraft Museum]] in 1978 was attended by fifteen former [[Battle of Britain]] pilots. It pays lasting tribute to all those airmen who fought in the skies over southern England during [[World War II]] and houses a substantial collection of aviation relics excavated by the group over many years from sites of crashed British and German aircraft, as well as items which have been donated.
Run by local enthusiasts, the Museum is largely funded by proceeds made by visitors whose donations contribute to the recovery and preservation of the artefacts. The Battle of Britain brought the village of Shoreham directly into the war when on 15 September 1940, a [[Dornier Do 17]]Z, part of a force of about 100 German bombers approaching London, was shot down shortly before noon. The invading formation had been challenged by nine [[Royal Air Force|RAF]] squadrons and the battle developed into a series of individual 'dogfights'. The unfortunate pilot of the Dornier was forced to land in a field at Castle Farm, with a [[Supermarine Spitfire|Spitfire]] circling overhead, its cockpit canopy open, and its pilot waving a handkerchief, to signal a warning to the growing crowd of hop-pickers nearby to stay away until the Shoreham [[British Home Guard|Home Guard]] arrived to recover the German crew. Feldwebel Heitsch, the pilot, and Feldwebel Pfeiffer, the observer, were driven to The Fox & Hounds pub in Knatts Valley, where they were bought a brandy before being driven to Sevenoaks Police Station. The museum holds a collection of photographs of the Dornier, along with items taken from the wreckage at the time.
==Shoreham duck race==
[[Image:ShorehamDuckRace.jpg|thumb|Shoreham duck race]] The Duck Race is a long-running event in the village. It is held each year, on the May Day bank holiday. Entrants pay a small fee (usually £1) to enter their 'duck' into the race. The duck has to travel along the river Darent from the war memorial in the village, to the bridge before the old Mill. A 'duck' can be anything from a shop-bought rubber duck to a model made by the entrant(s). Actual ducks are forbidden. It is a large event in the village and several hundred people turn out each year to line the riverbanks and watch. Anyone can enter and there is a prize for the 'Best Duck in Show' (awarded before the race begins) and the 'First placed Duck.' The money raised goes towards charitable organisations in the village.
==Television== The [[kitchen|''Showdown'' kitchen]] featured in ''[[The Big Family Cooking Showdown]]'' is a [[converted barn]] in Shoreham.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.whatsontv.co.uk/news/zoe-ball-on-cooking-showdown-im-not-the-greatest-cook-486377/|title=''The Big Family Cooking Showdown'' kitchen}}</ref>
==Notable events== On 29 September 1934, [[Airspeed Courier]] G-ACSY of [[London, Scottish & Provincial Airways Ltd]] crashed [[1934 London, Scottish & Provincial Airways Airspeed Courier crash|just north of Shoreham]], at the bottom of Cockerhurst Road.<ref name=EDP20090604>{{cite news | url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/norfolk-life/air_crash_mystery_1_598760 | title=Air crash mystery | date=4 June 2009 | newspaper=Eastern Daily Press | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140422184140/https://www.edp24.co.uk/norfolk-life/air_crash_mystery_1_598760 | archivedate=22 April 2014 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> The aircraft was on a scheduled international passenger flight from [[Heston Aerodrome|Heston]] to [[Le Bourget Airport|Paris]] and all four people on board were killed.
==Notable people== (in alphabetical order) * [[Robert Ashington Bullen]] (1850-1912), geologist and authority on [[mollusca]], was the vicar from 1888 to 1896. * [[Verney Lovett Cameron]] (1844–1894), first European to cross Equatorial Africa from coast to coast, buried in the village graveyard. * Robert Colgate, was a Shoreham farmer and a sympathiser with the [[French Revolution]] who, having been forced to leave Britain in 1793, travelled to the US where his son [[William Colgate]] founded the famous [[Colgate-Palmolive|Colgate]] company in 1806. * [[Shena Mackay]] (author) though born in Edinburgh, grew up in Shoreham.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/1999/jul/10/books.guardianreview8 |title=Bohemian rhapsodist | Books |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=2014-03-02}}</ref> * [[Edward Plunkett, 18th Baron Dunsany|Lord Dunsany]] (1878–1957), the writer, lived here, at Dunstall Priory, serving in the Home Guard during World War II, and is buried here, with his wife * London-born artist [[Samuel Palmer]], (1805–1881) lived in the village from 1826 to 1835 where he was part of a group of artists who followed [[William Blake]] (there is a theory that Blake took his inspiration for 'Jerusalem' from the village's surroundings) and called themselves ''The Ancients''. Palmer's work vividly depicts the local rural landscapes of the 1820s. Contrary to local myth, he did not live at the 'Water House' on the River Darent, but in a run-down farm cottage that has since been demolished. The mistake arises because his father, Samuel Palmer senior, rented the 'Water House' for some years. * [[Anthony Powell]], writer Powell's family lived at Dunstall Priory during the war and he visited whenever he was able to take leave from his duties at the [[War Office]]. * [[Joseph Prestwich]], geologist, lived in Shoreham until his death in 1896 * [[William Wall (theologian)|William Wall]], lived in Shoreham * [[Naomi Watts]] (born 28 September 1968), Hollywood actress, was born in Shoreham * [[John Wesley]] is known to have often preached here; he was friends of the then vicar. * [[Franklin White (dancer)|Franklin White]], ballet dancer<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news-gazette.com/obituaries/2013-05-30/peter-franklin-white.html |title=Peter Franklin-White |publisher=News-Gazette.com |date= |accessdate=2014-03-02}}</ref>
==Transport== ===Rail=== [[Shoreham railway station|Shoreham station]] provides the village with [[National Rail]] services to London via [[Bromley South railway station|Bromley South]], and to [[Sevenoaks railway station|Sevenoaks]].
===Buses=== * 421 to [[Swanley]] and to [[Sevenoaks]], ran by Go Coach Hire (Mondays to Saturdays)

revision.text:
{{Infobox industrial process | name = | image = Winter ski wax - Fort Devens Museum - DSC07132.JPG | caption = Vintage ski waxes, once used by [[U.S. Army]] [[Ski warfare|ski troops]]. Left to right are: ''grip waxes'' in canisters (blue for "dry snow" and yellow for "wet and corn snow") and a paraffin ''glide wax''. | type = | sector = Winter sports equipment and supplies | technologies = [[Tribology]] | feedstock = [[Paraffin wax]], [[resins]], [[fluorocarbon]]s | product = Glide wax, grip wax | companies = Briko-Maplus, Dakine, Dominator, [[Hertel Wax]], Holmenkol, Oneball, Purl, Rode, [[Swix]], Toko, Visti (Висти) | facility = | inventor = | year = | developer = }} '''Ski wax''' is a material applied to the bottom of snow runners, including [[ski]]s, [[snowboard]]s, and [[toboggan]]s, to improve their [[coefficient of friction]] performance under varying [[snow]] conditions. The two main types of wax used on skis are glide waxes and grip waxes. They address [[kinetic friction]]—to be minimized with a glide wax—and [[static friction]]—to be achieved with a grip wax. Both types of wax are designed to be matched with the varying properties of snow, including crystal type and size, and moisture content of the snow surface, which vary with temperature and the temperature history of the snow. Glide wax is selected to minimize sliding friction for both [[Alpine skiing|alpine]] and [[Cross-country skiing|cross-country]] skiing. Grip wax (also called "kick wax") provides on-snow traction for cross-country skiers, as they stride forward using [[Cross-country skiing#Classic|classic technique]].
Modern plastic materials (e.g. high-modulus polyethylene and Teflon), used on ski bases, have excellent gliding properties on snow, which in many circumstances diminish the added value of a glide wax. Likewise, uni-directional textures (e.g. fish scale or micro-scale hairs) underfoot on cross-country skis can offer a practical substitute for grip wax for those skiers, using the [[Cross-country skiing#Classic|classic]] technique.
== History == [[File:Martin Matsbo.jpg|thumb|right|Swedish ski racer, Martin Matsbo, pioneered development of modern cross-country ski waxes.]] Johannes Scheffer in ''Argentoratensis Lapponiæ'' (History of Lapland) in 1673 gave what is probably the first recorded instruction for ski wax application<ref name="Kuz01" /> He advised skiers to use pine tar pitch and rosin. Ski waxing was also documented in 1761.<ref>{{cite book|last=Oberleutnant Hals|title=Om Skismøring|publisher=Skienes Verden|location=Vaage|pages=254}}</ref>
Beginning around 1854, California gold rush miners held organized downhill ski races.<ref>{{cite web|title=Longboards at Mammoth|url=http://www.thestormking.com/tahoe_nuggets/Nugget_170/nugget_170.html|publisher=Mic Mac Publishing|accessdate=25 September 2012}}</ref> They also discovered that bases smeared with dopes brewed from vegetable and/or animal compound helped increase skiing speeds. This led to some of the first commercial ski wax (even though they contained no wax at all), such as ''Black Dope'' and ''Sierra Lighting''; both were mainly composed of [[whale oil|sperm oil]], vegetable oil and pine pitch. However, some instead used paraffin candle wax that melted onto ski bases, and these worked better under colder conditions.<ref name=gripandglide/>
Pine tar on wooden ski bases proved effective for using skis as transport over the centuries, because it fills the pores of the wood and creates an [[Hydrophobe|hydrophobic]] surface that minimizes suction from water in the snow, yet has sufficient roughness to allow traction for forward motion. In the 1920s and 30s, new varnishes were developed by European companies as season-long ski bases. A significant advance for cross country racing was the introduction of klister, for good traction in granular snow, especially in spring conditions; klister was invented and patented in 1913 by [[:no:Peter Østbye (skiprodusent)|Peter Østbye]]. In the early 1940s, a Swedish chemical company, advised by Olympic crosscountry skier [[Martin Matsbo]], started the development of petroleum-based waxes, using [[paraffin wax]] and other admixtures. By 1952, such noted brands as Toko, Swix and Rex were providing an array of color-coded, temperature-tailored waxes.<ref name=gripandglide>{{cite web|last1=Masia|first1=Seth|title=Grip and Glide: A Short History of Ski Wax |url=https://www.skiinghistory.org/history/grip-and-glide-short-history-ski-wax|accessdate=11 October 2014}}</ref>
In the last quarter of the 20th century, researchers addressed the twin problems of water and impurities adhering to skis during spring conditions. Terry Hertel addressed both problems, first with the novel use of a [[surfactant]] that interacted with the wax matrix in such a way as to repel water effectively, a product introduced in 1974 by [[Hertel Wax]]. Hertel also developed the first [[fluorocarbon]] product and the first spring-time wax that repels and makes the running surface slick for spring time alpine ski and snowboard. This technology was introduced to the market in 1986 by Hertel Wax.<ref name=gripandglide/> In 1990, Hertel filed for a U.S. patent on a "ski wax for use with sintered-base snow skis", containing paraffin, a hardener wax, roughly 1% per-fluoroether diol, and 2% SDS surfactant.<ref>{{ ref patent| country = US | number = 5114482 | status = patent | title = Ski wax for use with sintered base snow skis | pubdate = | gdate = May 19, 1992 | fdate = Mar 2, 1990 | pridate = | inventor = Terry J. Hertel | invent1 = | invent2 = | assign1 = | assign2 = | class = }}</ref> <!---Trademarks for Hertel waxes are Super HotSauce, Racing FC739, SpringSolution and White Gold.<ref name=gripandglide/> --->In the 1990s, [[Swix]] chief chemist Leif Torgersen found a glide wax additive to repel pollen and other snow impurities—a problem with soft grip waxes during distance races—in the form of a fluorocarbon that could be ironed into the ski base. The solution was based on the work of Enrico Traverso at [[:it:EniChem|Enichem SpA]], who had developed a fluorocarbon powder with a melting temperature just a few degrees below that of [[sintered polyethylene]],<ref name=gripandglide/> patented in Italy as a "ski lubricant comprising paraffinic wax and hydrocarbon compounds containing a perfluorocarbon segment".<ref>{{ref patent| country = US | number = 5202041 | status = patent | title = Ski lubricant comprising paraffinic wax and a hydrocarbon compound | pubdate = | gdate = Apr 13, 1993 | fdate = Mar 1, 1991 | pridate = | inventor = | invent1 = Enrico Traverso | invent2 = Antonio Rinaldi | assign1 = Enichem Synthesis S.p.A. | assign2 = | class = }}</ref>
==Science of sliding on snow== [[File:Snow friction vs water film thickness--Colbeck.png|thumb|Conceptual representation of sliding friction over snow, as a function of water film thickness, created by passage of a ski or other slider over a snow surface.]] The ability of a ski or other runner to slide over snow depends on both the properties of the snow and the ski to result in an optimum amount of lubrication from melting the snow by friction with the ski—too little and the ski interacts with solid snow crystals, too much and capillary attraction of meltwater retards the ski.
===Friction=== Before a ski can slide, it must overcome the maximum value static friction, <math>F_{max} = \mu_\mathrm{s} F_{n}\,</math>, for the ski/snow contact, where <math>\mu_\mathrm{s}</math> is the coefficient of static friction and <math> F_{n}\,</math> is the normal force of the ski on snow. Kinetic (or dynamic) friction occurs when the ski is moving over the snow.<ref name="Bhavikatti">{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=4wkLl4NvmWAC&pg=PA112&lpg=PA112 | title = Engineering Mechanics | last = Bhavikatti | first = S. S. |author2=K. G. Rajashekarappa | page = 112 | accessdate = 2007-10-21 | publisher = New Age International | isbn = 978-81-224-0617-7 | year = 1994}}</ref> The coefficient of kinetic friction, <math>\mu_\mathrm{k}</math>, is less than the coefficient of static friction for both ice and snow.<ref>{{cite book|title=Statics: Analysis and Design of Systems in Equilibrium|last=|first=|publisher=Wiley and Sons|year=2005|isbn=0-471-37299-4|location=|page=618|pages=|quote=In general, for given contacting surfaces, ''μ''<sub>k</sub> < ''μ''<sub>s</sub>|via=|author1=[[Sheri D. Sheppard|Sheppard, Sheri]]|author2=Tongue, Benson H.|author3=Anagnos, Thalia|lastauthoramp=yes}} </ref><ref name = Bowden/> The force required for sliding on snow is the product of the coefficient of kinetic friction and the normal force: <math>F_{k} = \mu_\mathrm{k} F_{n}\,</math>.<ref>{{cite book|author=Persson, B. N. J. |title=Sliding friction: physical principles and applications|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1jb-nZMnRGYC&q=kinetic+friction#v=snippet&q=kinetic%20friction&f=false|accessdate=2016-01-23|year=2000|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-3-540-67192-3}}</ref> Both the static and kinetic coefficients of friction increase with colder snow temperatures (also true for ice).<ref name = Bowden> {{cite journal | last = Bowden | first = F.P. | title = Ski and Snow | journal = New Scientist | volume = 21 | issue = 376 | pages = 275 | publisher = Reed Business Information | location = | date = January 30, 1964 | language = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=hgOxOlA8DcgC&pg=PA275&dq=Static+friction+snow+physics&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiF7868tbnKAhWJej4KHdswCEgQ6AEILzAD#v=snippet&q=%22Static%20friction%22&f=false | issn = 0262-4079 | access-date = 2016-01-21 }}</ref>
===Snow properties=== {{See also|Snow}} Snowflakes have a wide range of shapes, even as they fall; among these are: six-sided star-like [[Dendrite (crystal)|dendrites]], hexagonal needles, platelets and icy pellets. Once snow accumulates on the ground, the flakes immediately begin to undergo transformation (called ''metamorphosis''), owing to temperature changes, [[Sublimation (phase transition)|sublimation]], and mechanical action. Temperature changes may be from the ambient temperature, solar radiation, rainwater, wind, or the temperature of the material beneath the snow layer. Mechanical action includes wind and compaction. Over time, bulk snow tends to consolidate<ref> {{Citation | last = Colbeck | first = Samuel C. | title = A Review of Sintering in Seasonal Snow | journal = CRREL Report Series | volume = 97 | issue = 10 | pages = | date = December 1997 | url = http://www.inscc.utah.edu/~campbell/snowdynamics/reading/colbeck_sintering_1997.pdf | access-date = 2016-01-24 }}</ref>—its crystals become truncated from breaking apart or losing mass with sublimation directly from solid to gas and with freeze-thaw, causing them to combine as coarse and granular ice crystals.<ref> {{Citation | last = Working Group on Snow Classification | first = ICSI-UCCS-IACS | title = The International Classification for Seasonal Snow on the Ground | journal = IHP-VII Technical Documents in Hydrology | volume = 83 | issue = 1 | pages = 80 | date = 2009 | place = Paris | publisher = UNESCO | url = http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0018/001864/186462e.pdf | access-date = 2016-01-24 }}</ref><!---<ref name = Yankielun> {{cite book | last = Yankielun | first = Norbert E. | title = How to Build an Igloo: And Other Snow Shelters | publisher = W. W. Norton & Company | date = 2007 | location = | pages = 148 | language = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=bJR4nlnXdUAC&pg=PA4&lpg=PA4&dq=Yankielun,+Norbert+E.+(2007).+How+to+Build+an+Igloo:+And+Other+Snow+Shelters.+W.+W.+Norton+%26+Company&source=bl&ots=SKi7H5806G&sig=RPd2sA2Mj12s8wNx7smEpo6pluk&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi97uCki8HKAhWLPT4KHW_aB04Q6AEILDAC#v=onepage&q=metamorphosis&f=false | access-date = 2016-01-23 | isbn = 9780393732153 }} </ref>---> Colbeck reports that fresh, cold, and man-made snow all interact more directly with the base of a ski and increase friction, indicating the use of harder waxes. Conversely, older, warmer, and denser snows present lower friction, in part due to increased grain size, which better promotes a water film and a smoother surface of the snow crystals for which softer waxes are indicated.<ref name = Colbeck/> <center> ;Freshly fallen and metamorphosed snow crystals </center> <gallery mode="packed" heights="150px"> File:Wilson A. Bentley snowflake, 1890.jpg|Dendritic snowflake—[[micrograph]] by [[Wilson Bentley]]. File:Bentley snowflake micrograph no. 777.jpg|Platelets and needles, two alternate forms of snowflakes. File:Fresh dry snow forming bonds.png|Fresh, dry snow with newly formed bonds, showing a grain boundary (top center). File:Clustered ice grains in wet snow.png|Cluster of ice grains in wet snow at a low liquid content—grain crystals range 0.5 to 1.0 mm. </gallery>
===Ski friction properties=== Colbeck offers an overview of the five friction processes of skis on snow. They are the: 1) resistance due to plowing of snow out of the way, 2) deformation of the snow over which the ski is traveling, 3) lubrication of the ski with a thin layer of melt water, 4) capillary attraction of water in the snow to the ski bottom, and 5) contamination of the snow with dust and other non-slippery elements. Plowing and deformation pertain to the interaction of the ski, as a whole, with the snow and are negligible on a firm surface. Lubrication, capillary attraction and contamination are issues for the ski bottom and the wax that is applied to reduce sliding friction or achieve adequate grip.<ref name = Colbeck/>
Typically, a sliding ski melts a thin and transitory film of lubricating layer of water, caused by the heat of friction between the ski and the snow in its passing. Colbeck suggests that the optimum water film thickness is in the range between 4 and 12 [[Micrometre|''μ''m]]. However, the heat generated by friction can be lost by conduction to a cold ski, thereby diminishing the production of the melt layer. At the other extreme, when the snow is wet and warm, heat generation creates a thicker film that can create increased capillary drag on the ski bottom.<ref name = Colbeck> {{Citation | last = Colbeck | first = Samuel C. | title = A Review of the Processes That Control Snow Friction | journal =CRREL Monograph | volume =92 | issue = 2 | pages = 49 | date = April 1992 | url = http://acwc.sdp.sirsi.net/client/en_US/search/asset/1011800 | archive-url = | access-date = 2016-01-19 }} </ref> Kuzmin and Fuss suggest that the most favorable combination of ski base material properties to minimize ski sliding friction on snow include: increased hardness and lowered thermal conductivity of the base material to promote meltwater generation for lubrication, wear resistance in cold snow, and [[hydrophobe|hydrophobicity]] to minimize capillary suction. These attributes are readily achievable with a [[Polytetrafluoroethylene|PTFE]] base, which diminishes the value added by glide waxes.<ref name = Routledge> {{Citation | last = Kuzmin | first = Leonid | last2 = Fuss | first2 = Franz Konstantin | title = Cross country ski technology | journal = Routledge Handbook of Sports Technology and Engineering | publisher = Routledge | year = 2013 | month = | language = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=kRMKAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT233&lpg=PT233&dq=kick+wax+static+friction&source=bl&ots=fN_t5aueoA&sig=o4_PIJwn594Oxem2_H0ptHj5S3o&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwihi4uS67vKAhXJez4KHdjzA88Q6AEIJDAB#v=onepage&q=kick%20wax%20static%20friction&f=false | isbn = 9781136966590 }}</ref> Lintzén reports that factors other than wax are much more important in reducing friction on cross-country skate skis—the curvature of the ski and snow conditions.<ref> {{cite journal | last = Ahlbom | first = Helen | title = Glidvallan har marginell betydelse i Vasaloppet | journal = Nyteknik | location = Stockholm | date = February 29, 1916 | language = Swedish | url = http://www.nyteknik.se/nyheter/innovation/forskning_utveckling/article3964111.ece | access-date = 2016-03-11 }}</ref>
== Glide wax == Glide wax can be applied to alpine skis, snowboards, skate skis, classic skis, back-country skis, and touring skis. Traditional waxes comprise solid hydrocarbons. High-performance "fluorocarbon" waxes also contain fluorine which substitute some fraction of the hydrogen atoms in the hydrocarbons with fluorine atoms to achieve lower coefficients of friction and high water-repellency than the pure hydrocarbon wax can achieve.<ref name = Talbot> {{cite web | url = https://www.nensa.net/equipment/TheScienceofSkiWaxes.pdf | title = The science of ski waxes | last = Talbot | first = Chris | date = 2008 | website = | publisher = New England Nordic Ski Association | access-date = 2016-01-18 | quote = Basic ski wax is made from solid hydrocarbons. Some wax companies also sell wax that has fluorine in it. With these waxes, some, most, or all the hydrogen atoms in the hydrocarbons have been replaced with fluorine atoms. This new compound is called a fluorocarbon, and offers very low coefficients of friction and high water- repellency.}}</ref> Wax is adjusted for hardness to minimize sliding friction as a function of snow properties, which include the effects of:<ref name = Talbot/> *'''Age''': Reflects the metamorphosis of snow crystals that are sharp and well-defined, when new, but with aging become broken or truncated with wind action or rounded into ice granules with freeze-thaw, all of which affects a ski's coefficient of friction. *'''Moisture content''': The percentage of mass that is liquid water and may create suction friction with the base of the ski as it slides. *'''Temperature''': Affects the ease with which sliding friction can melt snow crystals at the interface between ski and snow.
===Properties=== A variety of glide waxes are tailored for specific temperature ranges and other snow properties with varying wax hardness and other properties that address repellence of moisture and dirt. The hardness of the glide wax affects the melting of the snow to lubricate its passage over the surface and its ability to avoid suction from meltwater in the snow. Too little melting and sharp edges of snow crystals or too much suction impede the passage of the ski. A tipping point between where crystal type dominates sliding friction and moisture content dominates occurs around 26 °F. Harder waxes address colder, drier or more abrasive snow conditions, whereas softer waxes have a lower coefficient of friction, but abrade more readily. Wax formulations combine three types of wax to adjust coefficient of friction and durability. From hard to soft, they include synthetic waxes with 50 or more carbon atoms, [[microcrystalline wax]]es with 25 to 50 carbon atoms and [[paraffin wax]]es with 20 to 35 carbon atoms.<ref name = Talbot/> Additives to such waxes include [[graphite]], [[teflon]], [[silicon]], [[fluorocarbons]], and [[molybdenum]] to improve glide and/or reduce dirt accumulation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Glide Wax|url=https://www.skiwax.ca/tp/glide.php|publisher=skiwax.ca|accessdate=11 October 2014}}</ref>
===Application=== Glide wax can be applied cold or hot. Cold applications include, rubbing hard wax like a crayon, applying a liquid wax or a spray wax.<ref name = XCwaxing> {{cite book | last = Brown | first = Nat | title = The Complete Guide to Cross-Country Ski Preparation | publisher = The Mountaineers Books | date = 1999 | location = Seattle | pages = 140 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=xLmmk_e-XCwC&pg=PA88&dq=glide+wax+application+technique&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi-oJqasrTKAhWIGj4KHVbhCaoQ6AEIKTAB#v=onepage&q=glide%20wax%20application%20technique&f=false | isbn = 9780898866001 }}</ref> Hot applications of wax include the use of heat from an iron, [[infrared]] lamp, or a "hot box" oven.<ref name="Kuz03">{{Cite thesis |type=Doctoral |title=Interfacial kinetic ski friction |url=http://miun.diva-portal.org/smash/get/diva2:319312/FULLTEXT01 |last=Kuzmin |first=Leonid |year=2010|publisher=Mid Sweden University |accessdate=2012-10-20 }}</ref>
===Base material=== The role of glide wax is to adapt and improve the friction properties of a ski base to the expected snow properties to be encountered on a spectrum from cold crystalline snow to saturated granular snow. Modern ski bases often are made from [[Ultra-high-molecular-weight polyethylene|ultra-high-molecular-weight polyethylene (UHMWPE)]]. Kuzmin asserts that UHMWPE is non-porous and can hold neither wax nor water, so there is no possibility for filling pores; furthermore, he asserts that UHMWPE is very hydrophobic, which means that wet snow does not appreciably retard the ski and that glide wax offers little additional ability to repel water. He notes that clear bases are more durable and hydrophobic than those with carbon content.<ref name="Kuz01">{{Cite thesis |type=Licentiate |title=Investigation of the most essential factors influencing ski glide |url=http://epubl.ltu.se/1402-1757/2006/03/LTU-LIC-0603-SE.pdf |last=Kuzmin |first=Leonid |year=2006 |publisher=Luleå University of Technology |accessdate=2012-10-20 }}</ref> The same author asserts that texture is more important than surface chemistry for creating the optimum balance between a running surface that's too dry (not slippery enough) and too wet (ski subject to suction forces). In warm, moist snow, texture can help break the retarding capillary attraction between the ski base and the snow.<ref name="Kuz03"/> Giesbrecht agrees that low wetting angle of the ski base is key and also emphasizes the importance of the degree of surface roughness at the [[micrometre]] scale as a function of snow temperature—cold snow favoring a smoother surface and wetter, warmer snow favoring a textured surface.<ref>{{Cite thesis |type=Doctoral |title=Polymers on snow: Towards skiing faster |url=http://e-collection.library.ethz.ch/eserv/eth:1160/eth-1160-02.pdf |last=Giesbrecht |first=Jan Lukas |year=2010 |publisher=Swiss Federal Institute of Technology |accessdate=2012-10-20 }}</ref> <!---Some authors question necessity to use any glide waxes on modern ski base <ref name="Kuz02">{{cite journal |last1=Kuzmin |first1=Leonid |last2=Tinnsten |first2=Mats |year=2006 |title=Dirt absorption on the ski running surface - quantification and influence on the gliding ability |journal=Sports Engineering |volume=9 |issue=13 |pages=137–146 |publisher= |doi=10.1007/BF02844115 |url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/t007g5307g247227/ |accessdate=2012-10-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Coupe |first1=Richard |year=2008 |title=An Investigation Comparing the Efficacy of Different Lubricants for Skis on Artificial Snow |journal=ENQUIRY: The ACES Journal of Undergraduate Research |volume=1 |issue=1 |pages= |publisher=Sheffield Hallam University |url=http://research.shu.ac.uk/aces/enquiry/index.php/enquiry/article/view/10/16 |accessdate=2012-10-20}}</ref>< Other authors insist that the ski base material already has very good sliding properties and can only be improved by a small margin by glide waxes in defined snow conditions. --->
== Grip wax == [[File:TipTop-Skiwachs.jpg|Canister of vintage German grip wax.|thumb|right]] [[File:Visti.jpg|thumb|right|Russian ''Visti'' (Висти)–brand klisters, graded by color and temperature range.]] <!----[[File:Ski wax - 2013-02-03 at 15-46-19.jpg|thumb|Red [[Swix]] grip wax. Used for classic style [[cross-country skiing]] when the snow is about {{convert|0|°C|°F}}.]] [[File:Visti.jpg|thumb|right|Soviet-era ''Visti'' (Висти)–brand klisters, graded by color and temperature range.]] [[File:Ski wax - 2013-02-03 at 15-50-07.jpg|thumb|Grip wax when applied to a ski.]]----> Cross-country skiers use a grip wax (also called "kick wax") for [[Cross-country skiing#Classic|classic-style waxable skis]] to provide traction with static friction on the snow that allows them to propel themselves forward on flats and up hills. They are applied in an area beneath the skier's foot and extending, somewhat forward, that is formed by the camber of the classic ski, called the "grip zone" (or "kick zone").<ref name="Rees">{{Cite book | edition = 3d | publisher = Copp C. Pitman | isbn = 978-0-7730-4045-8 | oclc = 300405310 | last = Rees | first = David| title = Cross-country skiing: touring and competition | location = Toronto | year = 1981}}</ref> The presence of camber allows the skis to grip the snow, when the weight is on one ski and the ski is fully flexed, but minimize drag when the skis are weighted equally and are thus less than fully flexed. Grip waxes are designed for specific temperature ranges and types of snow; a correctly selected grip wax does not appreciably decrease the glide of skis that have proper camber for the skier's weight and for the snow conditions.<ref name=gripandglide/> There are two substances used for grip wax: hard wax and klister. * '''Hard wax''': a traditionally [[paraffin wax]]-based substance with admixtures—for snow comprising crystals that are relatively intact and not substantially changed by packing or [[freeze-thaw]]. The admixtures, which include a dye, rubber, rosin, [[resin]] and [[colophony]],<ref name = Routledge/> adjust the hardness of the wax to tailor the effectiveness of its grip for specific, discrete temperature ranges (from approximately -25 °F to +35 °F); waxes are graded and color-coded according to these temperature ranges.<ref name=waxing/> Harder grip waxes are designed for colder snow temperatures, but grip poorly in warm temperatures. Conversely, softer waxes in cold temperatures create enough friction and melting that the melt layer may accumulate and promote frozen accretion of snow.<ref name = icing> {{cite web | url = http://crosscountryskitechnique.com/all-about-classic-skis/ | title = All About Classic Skis | last = McKenney | first = Kim | date = August 22, 2014 | website = Cross Country Ski Technique | publisher = | access-date = 2016-01-22 | quote = }}</ref>
* '''Klister''': a sticky ointment, which may contain a combination of rosins, waxes, solvents and fats<ref name=klister> {{cite book | last = NPCS Board of Consultants & Engineers | title = Selected Formulary Book on Petroleum, Lubricants, Fats, Polishes, Glass, Ceramics, Nitrogenous Fertilizers, Emulsions, Leather and Insecticides | publisher = Niir Project Consultancy Services | date = 2008 | location = | pages = 784 | language = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=zyEbAgAAQBAJ&pg=PP6&lpg=PP6&dq=klister+ski+wax+composition&source=bl&ots=oh9Fji-H58&sig=oo0cvOTZJ8_u4UFsgL0Ay37t-NM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjCv8uD_rPKAhVEej4KHSUNCY4Q6AEIUjAJ#v=onepage&q=klister%20ski%20wax&f=false | isbn = 9788190568562 }}</ref>—with the formulation tailored for snow that comprises coarse crystals, having been transformed through freeze-thaw or being wind-blown, and adjusted for specific temperature ranges. Spray-on klister is more convenient than klister applied from a tube.<ref name=gripandglide/><ref name=waxing> {{cite news | last = Woodward | first = Bob | title = Ski wax made (somewhat) simple—Confused by the wax rainbow? Maybe you've gone too far. | newspaper = Backpacker Magazine | location = | pages = 14 | language = | publisher = Active Interest Media, Inc.. | date = January 1985 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=698DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA14&dq=klister+wax&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi0tKiT-q_KAhUDNz4KHaEdAmUQ6AEIKTAB#v=onepage&q=klister%20wax&f=false | access-date = 2016-01-16}}</ref> An incorrect match of klister to snow conditions can also cause icing.<ref name = icing/>
Some skis are "waxless", having a fish-scale or other texture to prevent the ski from sliding backwards.<ref name=rei-grip>{{cite web|title=Grip Waxing Your Cross-Country Skis|url=http://www.rei.com/learn/expert-advice/grip-waxing-crosscountry-skis.html|publisher=REI|accessdate=11 October 2014}}</ref> [[Ski mountaineering|Ski mountaineers]] use temporarily adhered [[ski skins|climbing skins]] to provide uphill grip, but typically remove them for descent.<ref> {{cite book | last = Lind | first = David A. | last2 = Sanders | first2 = Scott | title = The Physics of Skiing: Skiing at the Triple Point | publisher = Springer Science & Business Media | series = | volume = | edition = 2 | date = 2013 | location = | pages = 270 | language = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=OpjuBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA161&dq=ski+climbing+skins&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjGwqD2nNLKAhVLbD4KHSKKA0oQ6AEIQTAD#v=onepage&q=climbing%20skins&f=false | access-date = 2016-01-30 | isbn = 1475743459 }}</ref> <gallery mode="packed" heights="150px"> File:Melting ski wax.jpg|Melting glide wax onto a skate ski to be ironed in and scraped smooth. File:Application of grip wax to a classic cross-country ski.jpg|Application of grip wax to a classic cross-country ski, using a canister of wax, like those shown in the left foreground. File:Smoothing of grip wax on a classic cross-country ski.jpg|Smoothing of grip wax on a classic cross-country ski, using a hand-held "cork", like the item marked "Swix" in the right foreground. </gallery>
== Wax solvents ==
Wax can be dissolved by [[Chemical polarity#Nonpolar molecules|non-polar]] [[Solvent#Properties table of common solvents|solvent]]s like [[mineral spirits]].<ref name=klister/> However, some commercial wax solvents are made from [[limonene|citrus oil]], which is less toxic, harder to ignite, and gentler on the ski base.<ref> {{cite web | url = https://www.reliableracing.com/downloads/1c41c5be75.pdf | title = Nordic Ski Preparation—Waxing Guide for Skating and Classic Skiing | date = | website = | publisher = Swix | access-date = 2016-01-20 | quote = }}</ref>
==Health and environmental effects==
=== Health ===
Ski wax may contain chemicals with potential health affects including perfluorinated chemicals. Levels of [[perfluorinated carboxylic acid]]s, especially [[perfluorooctanoic acid|perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA)]], have been shown to increase in ski wax technicians during the ski season.<ref name="Nilsson"> {{Citation | last = Nilsson | first = Helena | last2 = Kärrman | first2 = Anna | last3 = Håkan | first3 = Westberg | last4 = Rotander | first4 = Anna | last5 = van Bavel | first5 = Bert | last6 = Lindström | first6 = Gunilla | title = A Time Trend Study of Significantly Elevated Perfluorocarboxylate Levels in Humans after Using Fluorinated Ski Wax | journal = Environmental Science and Technology | volume = 44 | issue = 6 | pages = 2150–5 | date = March 15, 2010 | url = http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/es9034733 | doi =10.1021/es9034733 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Katz|first1=Cheryl|title=Ski Wax Chemicals Can Build Up in Blood|url=https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/ski-wax-chemicals-buildup-blood/|website=Scientific American|accessdate=4 April 2017}}</ref>
=== Environment ===
When skiing, the friction between the snow and skis causes wax to abrade and remain in the snow pack until spring thaw.<ref> {{Citation | last = Plassmann | first = Merle M. | title = Environmental occurrence and fate of semifluorinated n-alkanes and perfluorinated alkyl acids present in ski waxes | journal = Department of Applied Environmental Science | publisher = Stockholm University | date = 2011 | url = http://www.diva-portal.org/smash/get/diva2:411051/FULLTEXT01.pdf }}</ref> Then the snowmelt drains into watersheds, streams, lakes and rivers, thereby changing the chemistry of the environment and the food chain. Perfluorocarbons in ski wax are heat resistant, chemically and biologically stable, and thus environmentally persistent.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/317725/PFOS_and_PFOA_properties_incident_management_toxicology.pdf|title=PFOS and PFOA General Information|author1=Centre for Radiation|author2=Chemical and Environmental Hazards|date=2009|website=|publisher=Public Health England|access-date=2016-01-23|quote=}}<!---Bull, S. "PFOS + PFOA Toxicological Overview." Health Protection Agency. 2009. Web. 25 Mar. 2012. <http://www.hpa.org.uk/webc/HPAwebFile/HPAweb_C/1246260032570>---></ref>

[[Italy national football team]] (selected matches) | seating_capacity = 23,860 }} [[File:Stadio "La fiorita" a Cesena nel 1957.jpg|250px|thumbnail|right|Stadio La Fiorita in 1957.]] The '''Stadio Dino Manuzzi''', also known as '''Orogel Stadium''' for sponsorship reason, is a [[association football|football]] stadium in [[Cesena]], Italy. It is currently the home of [[A.S.D. Romagna Centro Cesena]]. The stadium holds 23,860. The stadium was initially constructed in 1957 but at the time had no seats, just two terraces. In 1973, when AC Cesena reached Serie A status, the stadium was greatly expanded and could hold 30,000 spectators. In this version of the stadium, the highest ever attendance was recorded when on 10 February 1974, 35,991 people watched Cesena defeat giants AC Milan. The stadium was called '''La Fiorita''' from its construction until 1982, when it became named after former Cesena president Dino Manuzzi. In 1988 the stadium underwent a complete restructuring were all of the existing stands were demolished and then rebuilt. The new capacity was reduced to 23,860. As a part of Italy's Euro 2016 bid, the Dino Manuzzi was included and there were plans to invest close to €30m on the stadium. The planned changes included an increase in capacity to over 31,000 new press boxes, VIP lounges and media boxes. This fell through after Euro 2016 was awarded to France. At the beginning of the 2011/12 season, the pitch was converted to an artificial playing surface, with Cesena becoming the first club to do so. On 13 August 2011, at the end of the Italy - Japan rugby match, fans were allowed to enter the pitch and take a cut out of grass with them. That same summer some further work was carried out on the stadium, including a capacity expansion by 1,000 seats. New chairs were installed. The chairs were a white and black colour and on one terrace they spell out AC Cesena. Two Plexiglas boxes were also installed on the side of the pitch, each holding eight supporters, where the fans can track the progress of the match from just a few meters away. In 2014, {{ill|Orogel|it}} signed a sponsorship agreement with [[A.C. Cesena]], the tenant of the stadium. The stadium would be called '''Orogel Stadium – Dino Manuzzi'''.{{cite news|url=https://www.ilrestodelcarlino.it/cesena/sport/calcio/accesena-stadio-orogel-stadium-1.246459|title=Cesena, il Manuzzi diventa Orogel Stadium|date=26 September 2014|accessdate=13 October 2018|newspaper=[[Il Resto del Carlino]]|language=Italian}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website}} {{it icon}} {{Coord|44|8|26|N|12|15|43|E|type:landmark_region:IT|display=title}} {{S-start}} {{Succession box| title=[[UEFA Women's Euro]]

(Corporate Anniversaries) (Company Profile)|first=Maria|last=Torres|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-14361503.html|work=Hawaii Business|date=June 1, 1993|accessdate=February 11, 2015}} | former_names = Special Events Arena (1994–1998) | tenants = [[University of Hawaii at Manoa|Hawaii Rainbow Wahine]] (women's basketball, women's volleyball)

[[Diamond Head Classic]] | seating_capacity = 10,300 }} The '''Stan Sheriff Center''' is a 10,300-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Honolulu CDP]],"[http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/MapItDrawServlet?geo_id=16000US1517000&_bucket_id=50&tree_id=420&context=saff&_lang=en&_sse=on Honolulu CDP, HI]." ''[[U.S. Census Bureau]]''. Retrieved on May 21, 2009. [[City and County of Honolulu]], [[Hawaii]], on the campus of the [[University of Hawaii at Manoa]]. Initially named the '''Special Events Arena''' when it opened in 1994, the arena was renamed in 1998 after [[Stan Sheriff]] (1932–1993), a former UH athletic director who lobbied for its construction. ==Events== Stan Sheriff Center is home to the [[University of Hawaii at Manoa|University of Hawai{{okina}}i]] men's [[Hawaii Rainbow Warriors basketball|Rainbow Warriors basketball]] and [[Hawaii Rainbow Warriors|Warriors]] [[volleyball]], and the women's [[Hawaii Rainbow Wahine|Rainbow Wahine]] [[basketball]], and [[Hawaii Rainbow Wahine volleyball|Rainbow Wahine volleyball]] teams. The [[Diamond Head Classic]] midseason [[college basketball]] tournament is held in December.http://www.diamondheadclassic.com/about.html and the annual regional [[FIRST Robotics Competition]] On May 12, 1998, the [[Miss Universe]] pageant was held at the Center.[http://archives.starbulletin.com/1998/04/07/news/story1.html Pageant has isles sitting pretty] As Hawaii's largest indoor arena, the Stan Sheriff Center is the site of many major concert tours in Honolulu. Concert capacity is 11,000 for an end-stage show and 11,300 for a center-stage show. [[World Championship Wrestling]] used the Stan Sheriff Center as its Hawaiian stop from 1994 until the organization folded in 2001. The arena hosted two NBA preseason games between the [[Los Angeles Lakers]] and [[Utah Jazz]] on October 4 and 6, 2015. Both were designated as Lakers home games; the Jazz swept the short series, winning the second game in overtime. The arena again hosted two NBA preseason games between the [[Los Angeles Clippers]] and [[Toronto Raptors]] on October 1 and 3, 2017. Toronto ended up winning the first game, while the Clippers won the second game. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://hawaiiathletics.com/sports/2008/5/14/stan_sheriff_center.aspx? Official page for the Stan Sheriff Center] from the UH Athletics web site {{University of Hawaii at Manoa}} {{Hawaii Rainbow Warriors basketball navbox}} {{Hawaii Rainbow Wahine basketball navbox}} {{Big West Conference basketball venue navbox}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | title=[[Miss Universe]] Venue| before=[[Miami Beach Convention Center]] | after=Chaguaramas Convention Centre'' | years=1998 }} {{end}} [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:College volleyball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Hawaii]] [[Category:Hawaii Rainbow Warriors and Rainbow Wahine basketball]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Honolulu]] [[Category:University of Hawaii]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1994]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1994]] [[Category:1994 establishments in Hawaii]]

{{Infobox college coach | name = Tates Locke | image = | alt = | caption = | sport = [[Basketball]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1937|2|25}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = | player_years1 = 1957–1959 | player_team1 = [[Ohio Wesleyan Battling Bishops men's basketball|Ohio Wesleyan]] | player_positions = | coach_years1 = 1959–1960 | coach_team1 = [[Ohio Wesleyan Battling Bishops men's basketball|Ohio Wesleyan]] (assistant) | coach_years2 = 1960–1963 | coach_team2 = [[Army Black Knights men's basketball|Army]] (assistant) | coach_years3 = 1963–1965 | coach_team3 = [[Army Black Knights men's basketball|Army]] | coach_years4 = 1965–1966 | coach_team4 = [[Army Black Knights men's basketball|Army]] (freshmen) | coach_years5 = 1966–1970 | coach_team5 = [[Miami RedHawks men's basketball|Miami (OH)]] | coach_years6 = 1970–1975 | coach_team6 = [[Clemson Tigers men's basketball|Clemson]] | coach_years7 = 1975–1976 | coach_team7 = [[Buffalo Braves]] (assistant) | coach_years8 = 1976–1977 | coach_team8 = [[Buffalo Braves]] | coach_years9 = 1978–1981 | coach_team9 = [[Jacksonville Dolphins men's basketball|Jacksonville]] | coach_years10 = 1981–1983 | coach_team10 = [[UNLV Runnin' Rebels basketball|UNLV]] (assistant) | coach_years11 = 1987–1989 | coach_team11 = [[Indiana Hoosiers men's basketball|Indiana]] (assistant) | coach_years12 = 1989–1994 | coach_team12 = [[Indiana State Sycamores men's basketball|Indiana State]] | overall_record = 255–254 (college)
16–30 (NBA) | bowl_record = | tournament_record = 1–3 ([[NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament|NCAA University Division / Division I]])
6–4 ([[National Invitation Tournament|NIT]]) | championships = [[Mid-American Conference|MAC]] regular season (1969)
[[Sun Belt Conference Men's Basketball Tournament|Sun Belt Tournament]] ([[1979 Sun Belt Conference Men's Basketball Tournament|1979]]) | awards = [[Missouri Valley Conference Men's Basketball Coach of the Year|MVC Coach of the Year]] (1991) | coaching_records = }} '''Taylor "Tates" Locke''' (born February 25, 1937) is an American former [[basketball]] coach. Locke coached the [[Buffalo Braves]] of the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA) for half a season, in 1976–77, before being replaced by [[Bob MacKinnon]]. Prior to his Buffalo experience, Locke coached for [[United States Military Academy|West Point]], where he hired a young assistant coach named [[Bobby Knight]]. Knight would later replace Locke when Locke left West Point. After West Point, Locke moved on to [[Miami University]] in [[Oxford, Ohio]], winning a MAC title in 1968-69. Locke would subsequently coach at [[Clemson University]], but would be forced to resign as the result of an [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] investigation into recruiting violations. The violation resulted in the Tigers being put on NCAA probation. He later coached at [[Jacksonville University]] and took them to an NCAA berth and [[National Invitation Tournament|NIT]] berth. Locke would became the head coach at [[Indiana State University]] and served as a scout and assistant general manager for the [[Portland Trail Blazers]]. The movie ''[[Blue Chips]]'', starring [[Nick Nolte]], is said to be based on Locke's career. However, several midwestern college coaches claim to be the inspiration for the character. ==Head coaching record== ===College=== {{CBB Yearly Record Start | type = | conference = | postseason = | {{Infobox stadium | name = Titan Gym | nickname = | image = [[Image:TitanGym2.jpg|250px|Inside of Titan Gym]] | fullname = Titan Gym | former_names = | location = 800 North State College Blvd.
[[Fullerton, California|Fullerton]], [[California|CA]] 92834 | coordinates = {{coord|33.883046|-117.886090|type:landmark|display=it}} | broke_ground = | built = 1964 | opened = | renovated = 2004 | expanded = 2005 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[California State University, Fullerton]] | operator = California State University, Fullerton | surface = Hardwood | construction_cost = | architect = | capacity = 4,000 | record_attendance = 5,015 | tenants = [[Cal State Fullerton Titans men's basketball]]
[[Cal State Fullerton Titans women's basketball]]
[[Cal State Fullerton Titans women's volleyball]] }} '''Titan Gym''' is a 4,000 seat, indoor [[multi-purpose stadium]] on the campus of [[California State University, Fullerton]] in [[Fullerton, California|Fullerton]], [[California]]. ==History and renovations== [[Image:TitanGym1.jpg|250px|left|Exterior of Titan Gym]] Titan Gym was built in 1964.{{cite web |title=Daniels Comes Back to Basics |date=14 November 2000 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2000/nov/14/sports/sp-51488?pg=3 |accessdate=8 October 2009}} Twenty years later, the gym hosted [[Handball at the 1984 Summer Olympics|handball]] competitions for the [[1984 Summer Olympics]].{{cite web |title=Milestones of Cal State Fullerton |date= |work=[http://www.titanmag.com/ Titan Magazine] |url=http://www.titanmag.com/2007/milestones/index.html |accessdate=8 October 2009}}[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1984/1984v1pt1.pdf 1984 Summer Olympics official report.] Volume 1. Part 1. pp. 135-6. [[Ronald Reagan]] spoke on behalf of the [[George H. W. Bush|Bush]]/[[Dan Quayle|Quayle]] campaign in 1988, his last [[Orange County, California|Orange County]] appearance as [[President of the United States]]. In order to combat wear and tear on Titan Gym, there have been a number of improvements made. Bleachers, which were used to seat the attendees, have been replaced with chair-back seats. The floor was completely redesigned and resurfaced. A new scoreboard was unveiled before the 2003 season and additional balcony seating was added before the start of the 2004 season. For the [[Cal State Fullerton Titans|CSUF]] athletes, Titan Gym is also the home practice facility for the basketball and volleyball programs. The [[2018 U.S. Open (badminton)|2018 U.S. Open]], a stop on the [[2018 BWF World Tour|2018 Badminton World Federation Tour]], was held at the gym.{{cite web|title=Yonex US Badminton Open (Prospectus)|url=http://bwfextranet.com/docs/events/3216/docs/US%20Open%202018%20_%20Prospectus%20Final%20_%20v1.10.pdf|publisher=[[Badminton World Federation]]|accessdate=7 July 2018|date=2018}} Future renovation plans include an expansion of the Titan Gym entrance to include a Titans Hall of Fame as well as a reception area for social functions. ==Tenants== Currently the men's basketball, women's basketball and women's volleyball call Titan Gym home. The men's basketball team has played every season at Titan Gym since its opening in 1964. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.fullertontitans.com/athletics/titan_gym Cal State Fullerton athletic facilities] * [http://www.lasports.org/lafacilities/display.php?s=Arena&id=31 Titan Gymnasium (CSUF)] {{Cal State Fullerton Titans men's basketball navbox}} {{Big West Conference basketball venue navbox}} {{1984 Summer Olympic venues}} {{Olympic venues handball}} {{Orange County Sports}} [[Category:Basketball venues in California]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Fullerton, California]] [[Category:Cal State Fullerton Titans men's basketball]] [[Category:Cal State Fullerton Titans women's basketball]] [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:College volleyball venues in the United States]] [[Category:College wrestling venues in the United States]] [[Category:Handball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in California]] [[Category:Olympic handball venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Fullerton, California]] [[Category:Volleyball venues in California]] [[Category:Wrestling venues in California]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1964]] [[Category:1964 establishments in California]] [[Category:Venues of the 1984 Summer Olympics]]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Turner Stadium | nickname = | image = File:Turner Stadium.jpg | caption = '''[[UEFA stadium categories|UEFA Category 4 Stadium]]''' | fullname = Yaakov Turner Toto Stadium Be'er Sheva | location = [[Be'er Sheva]], Israel | coordinates = {{Coord|31|16|23.34|N|34|46|45.7|E|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = August 2011 | built = | opened = September 2015 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Be'er Sheva|City of Be'er Sheva]] | operator = [[Be'er Sheva|City of Be'er Sheva]] | surface = Grass | construction_cost = [[Israeli new shekel|₪]]250 million | services engineer = | general_contractor= | main_contractors = | tenants = [[Hapoel Be'er Sheva F.C.|Hapoel Be'er Sheva]] (2015–present)
[[Israel national football team]] | seating_capacity = 16,126 | dimensions = 22.000 Sq m }} The '''Turner Stadium''' ({{lang-he-n|אצטדיון טרנר}}), officially the '''Yaakov Turner Toto Stadium Be'er Sheva''' (Hebrew: {{Hebrew|אצטדיון טוטו באר שבע ע"ש יעקב טרנר}}) is a [[association football|football]] stadium in [[Be'er Sheva]] and the home ground of [[Hapoel Be'er Sheva F.C.|Hapoel Be'er Sheva]]. It was named for former Be'er Sheva mayor [[Yaakov Turner]]. The stadium has an all-seated capacity of 16,126 seats, with the southern stand named after Arthur Vasermil, for whom the club's previous [[Vasermil Stadium]] was named. and is a part of a [[sports complex]] which also includes the multi-purpose 3,000-seat [[Conch Arena]], a [[training field]] and a [[swimming pool]]. ==History== The stadium, located on the northern side of Beer Sheva,[http://www.jewishagency.org/beer-sheva-bnei-shimon-and-montreal/content/41016 Stadium in Beer Sheva] opened during the early stages of the [[2015–16 Israeli Premier League|2015–16 season]], with the club selling a record 12,000 season tickets.[http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Sports/Beersheba-cuts-the-ribbon-on-Israels-newest-soccer-stadium-416350 Beersheba cuts the ribbon on Israel’s newest soccer stadium] The Jerusalem Post, 17 September 2015 However, as it was not ready for the start of the season, Hapoel were forced to play their first home match at the [[Teddy Stadium]] in [[Jerusalem]].[http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Sports/Maccabi-TA-edges-Beersheba-thanks-to-Zahavi-413766 Maccabi TA edges Beersheba thanks to Zahavi] The Jerusalem Post, 31 August 2015 The first match at the ground was played on 21 September 2015, a 0–0 draw with [[Maccabi Haifa F.C.|Maccabi Haifa]].[http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Sports/Beersheba-opens-stadium-with-goalless-deadlock-417846 Beersheba opens stadium with goalless deadlock] The Jerusalem Post, 22 September 2015 ==See also== *[[Sports in Israel]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.turnerstadium.co.il/ Official website] {{Israeli Premier League}} [[Category:Football venues in Israel]] [[Category:Sports venues in Beersheba]] [[Category:Hapoel Be'er Sheva F.C.]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2015]] [[Category:2015 establishments in Israel]]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Western Hall | nickname = | image = | location = [[Macomb, Illinois]] | broke_ground = | opened = 1964 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Western Illinois University]] | operator = [[Western Illinois Leathernecks|Western Illinois Athletics]] | surface = Hardwood | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Western Illinois Leathernecks]]
([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) | seating_capacity = 5,139 }} '''LeRoy A. Ufkes Court at Western Hall''' is a 5,139-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Macomb, Illinois]]. It was built in 1964. It is home to the [[Western Illinois University]] [[Western Illinois Leathernecks|Leathernecks]] [[Western Illinois Leathernecks men's basketball|men's]]http://www.goleathernecks.com/ViewArticle.dbml?&DB_OEM_ID=12000&ATCLID=623296 and [[Western Illinois Leathernecks women's basketball|women's]]http://www.goleathernecks.com/ViewArticle.dbml?&DB_OEM_ID=12000&ATCLID=205342493 [[basketball]] teams and the women's [[volleyball]] [[team]].http://www.goleathernecks.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=12000&ATCLID=623348 ==History and features== Completed in 1964, its stadium-style seats, combined with bleachers in the upper levels, accommodate 5,139 fans surrounding the maple wood floor. The playing surface in Western Hall has undergone several changes in its history. Originally a wooden floor, the regulation-size court was replaced with a tartan floor in 1973 and, prior to the 1993-94 basketball season, upgraded with a parquet floor similar to that in the old [[Boston Garden]]. In 2014, the parquet floor was replaced with a maple wood floor. The court is surrounded by a Chem-turf jogging track. The building underwent massive construction in 1997 with the addition of the $8 million Student Recreation Center to its south. The SRC serves as host to all intramural and club sports, and houses a swimming pool, racquetball courts, suspended jogging track and state-of-the-art exercise equipment. In the summer of 1999, the court received a face lift with a new floor design featuring Rocky, the WIU mascot, and it was refinished during the summer of 2000. The latest addition to Western Hall, a new training facility for all WIU athletic programs and locker room for the Leatherneck football program which was added onto the East Arena, was completed in July, 2000. ==Events== Besides serving as the home for varsity basketball and volleyball, Western Hall houses numerous athletic and physical education activities and many major Bureau of Cultural Affairs events, including concerts, musicals and multi-cultural entertainment events for all ages. One of the highlights of the 1999-2000 BCA season was an appearance by [[Bill Cosby]]. ==See also== * [[Western Illinois Leathernecks men's basketball]] * [[Western Illinois Leathernecks women's basketball]] * [[Western Illinois Leathernecks]] * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://goleathernecks.com/sports/2014/6/6/facilities_0606144658.aspx?id=28 Western Hall - The Official Athletics Site of the Western Illinois University Leathernecks] {{Western Illinois Leathernecks men's basketball navbox}} {{Western Illinois University}} {{Summit League basketball venue navbox}} {{Coord|40.471589|-90.685201|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Basketball venues in Illinois]] [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:College volleyball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Illinois]] [[Category:Volleyball venues in Illinois]] [[Category:Western Illinois Leathernecks men's basketball]] [[Category:Western Illinois Leathernecks women's basketball]] [[Category:Western Illinois Leathernecks sports venues]] [[Category:1964 establishments in Illinois]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1964]] {{Illinois-sports-venue-stub}}

{{refimprove|date=February 2018}}{{primary|date=February 2018}}{{for|other cups with the same name|Wimbledon Cup (disambiguation)}} The Wimbledon Cup is a marksmanship trophy that was established in the 1870s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nra.org/Article.aspx?id=788 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040831054534/http://www.nra.org/Article.aspx?id=788 |archive-date=August 31, 2004 |accessdate=January 16, 2018 |title=Tubb is NRA 2004 Long Range Champion |publisher=NRA}}</ref>
[[File:Wimbledon Cup.jpg|thumb|The Wimbledon Cup for rifle shooting marksmanship]]
It is awarded annually during the [[National Rifle & Pistol Matches]] which are held at [[Camp Perry]], Ohio.
Each year the high-power phase of these matches traditionally takes place during the first two weeks of August. The Wimbledon Cup is awarded for the winner of a 1000-yard shooting match — in which the rules permit use of "any sight", including telescopes.
Concurrent with the Wimbledon, [[High power rifle|service rifle]] shooters compete for the Farr Trophy, and [[International Confederation of Fullbore Rifle Associations|Palma]] rifle shooters vie for the "Doc" Aiken Trophy.
==History== The Wimbledon Cup is a silver tankard wrought by British silversmiths of the Victorian period.
The [[National Rifle Association of the United Kingdom]] inaugurated the prize in 1866. The [[Illustrated London News]] reported on July 26, 1866, that the Wimbledon Cup was a new prize for the Wimbledon Rifle Meeting of that year.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.iln.org.uk/iln_years/year/1866.htm|title=New Prizes at The Wimbledon Volunteer Rifle Meeting |date=July 26, 1866|work=Illustrated London News}}</ref>
In 1875, the trophy was presented to the American rifle team attending the British matches at [[Wimbledon, London|Wimbledon]] by Princess Louise, on behalf of the riflemen of Great Britain. Members of the American team competed among themselves for the trophy at Wimbledon; this match was won by Major Henry Fulton. The Wimbledon Cup was taken to the United States and placed in annual competition at [[Creedmoor Rifle Range]] as the trophy for a long range match open to any rifle. Michelle Gallagher has won the most cups with five. Her family have won it seven times. Her mother Nancy H. Tompkins-Gallagher won once and her step-father Middleton W. Tompkins won once.
The 1965 Trophy was awarded to [[Carlos Hathcock|LCPL Carlos N. Hathcock, USMC]].
==References== *{{cite web|url=http://www.nrahq.org/compete/champ3.asp|accessdate=2006-12-14|title=NRA National High Power Rifle Long Range Championships|work=Competitive Shooting Programs|publisher=National Rifle Association}}
